‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ü‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É

PREFACE.

<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1729583069‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§è‡§Æ‡•ç.png"/>

The idea of preparing an edition of Udbha·π≠a’s KƒÅvyƒÅla·πÅkƒÅra-sƒÅra-sa·πÅgraha was conceived as far back as theyear 1898 under peculiar circumstances. The editor was, at the time, in charge of the Government MSS. Library atthe Deccan College, and as such he had to examine and readthe MSS. carefully. The collections of 1872-73, 1873-74and 1874-75, acquired for the Government by Dr. B√ºhler, consisted of very rare and valuable works on Ala·πÅkƒÅra, Kashmirian History and General Literature. A good MS. ofUdbhata’s work with the commentary of IndurƒÅja amongthem attracted the notice of the editor as being a fit subjectfor careful study. The celebrity of the author Udbha»õa,whose name was familiar to the readers of KƒÅvyaprakƒÅ≈õaof Mammata, who along withƒÄnandavardhana, Ruyyaka and JagannƒÅtha mentions him with great respect, togetherwith the acuteness and learning of the commentatorIndurƒÅja, added to the solicitude of the editor for taking upthe work immediately. Accordingly he started preparing the text with a view to edit it in the Bombay SanskritSeries; and the necessary permission of the EducationalDepartment was obtained in the year 1900 for the inclusionof the work in the Series. The work of the edition was beingcarried on along with his official and other duties. In course of time the press copy of the text was prepared, but beforeany arrangement for printing could be made the editorwas, in 1907, suddenly transferred from his post at theDeccan College. Owing to the transfer from Poona to other inconvenient places and owing to various othercauses the work of this edition was laid aside indefinitely,till at the suggestion of the authorities at the BhandarkarOriental Research Institute (to whose care, in the mean while, the management and publication of the B. S. Series

was transferred) it was taken up again. During the closing months of 1919 and the beginning of 1920 the work of finally preparing the edition for the press was pushed through and the complete press copy was delivered to the B.O.R. Institute in August 1920. The press copy lay with the Bhandarkar Institute for two more years awaiting the printer. One was at last found and the printing began in about October 1922 which, however, took three more years. Such is the very long history of the present edition.

CRITICAL NOTICE OF THE M

SS

.

Two MSS. have been utilized in preparing this Edition. The first, coming from the Deccan College, is No. 64 of the 1873‚Äì74 Collection at the Deccan College MSS. Library (now deposited at the B.O.R. Institute, Poona). This MS. named ‚ÄòUdbha·π≠ƒÅla·πÅkƒÅra Laghu»õikƒÅsahita‚Äôwas bought for the MSS. Library by Dr. G. B√ºhler in one of his famous tours, in search of Sanskrit MSS., made in Kashmir, Rajputana and Central India. This particular MS. was obtained at Jesalmir in his tour of 1873-74. It is a new copy made by a scribe from the original, in fairly legible and bold NƒÅgar√Ø characters. It contains 62 folios with 26 lines on each folio written on one side only. It begins thus:‚Äî ‡••‡§®‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø‡•• ‡§Ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç etc., and ends in this manner:‚Äî

‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø‡§¨‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§£‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§É‡•• ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§É‡•• ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡•ß‡•Ø‡•©‡•¶ ‡§´‡§æ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡•Ä ‡•ß‡•™

‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡•Ä‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡•á‡§®‡••

The text of Udbha»õa and IndurƒÅja presented in this Edition is mainly based on this MS.

Another MS. containing Udbhata’s text and a commentary different from that of IndurƒÅja is deposited in the Govt. MSS. Library, Madras. This also is a transcript from the original. A description of it as kindly furnished to me by the Curator, is as follows:‚Äî

‚ÄúPaper 10

‚Å∑/‚Çà

√ó 9

‚Åµ/‚Çà

Foll. 34. Lines 20 in a page. DevanƒÅgar√¨: good.

Transcribed in 1919-20 from a MS. of M. R. Ry. Narayana Nambudripad, Kudalur Mana, Narcri, Malabar Dt. Folios 1 a to 336. Folio 34 is left blank. Contains Vargas 1 to 6 complete."

A specially prepared copy of this MS. was obtained for this Edition, for which the thanks of the Editor are due to the Curator, Prof. S. Kuppuswamy Sastri, avl., M. A. The transcript was received when the printing of the text was fairly advanced. Hence the variant readings had to be given in the form of an Appendix at the end, as the results of collation could not be availed of in printing the text. As the commentary was a new one it was thought advisable to give copious extracts from it in the notes. This has gone to swell the bulk of the Notes to a great extent.

Owing to the fact that the work of this Edition was done at different periods separated by long intervals of inaction, its execution has not been as satisfactory as it was desired to be. Owing to the advent of the Madras MS. and other material at a very late stage, the original arrangement was rather disturbed. The most regrettable misfortune in editing works of this type, viz. inaccuracy of Indian printing, has also cursed this volume in no small measure. Consequently a fairly long list of ‘Additions and Corrections’ has to be given which should be kindly consulted before reading the text.

The Notes are designed to meet theneeds of the advanced student of Ala·πÅkƒÅra Literature. They are explanatory in the first instance, and after explaining the text clearly they attempt to give to the reader a distinct idea of the historical development of ala·πÅkƒÅras from BhƒÅmaha to Mamma·π≠a through Udbha·π≠a and IndurƒÅja. If what is presented here causes some lovers of Sanskrit Literature to appreciate the really invaluable pioneer work done by Udbha·π≠a in the field of Ala·πÅkƒÅra the labour spent on the work will be deemed to be amply repaid.

THE EDITOR.

( *)*(*)It was thought unnecessary to append a listof abbreviations of works, references to which occur in theIntroduction and the Notes. As a rule abbreviations arenot used and where they are used they are such as would be easily intelligible, e.g. ‡§™‡§æ. for ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§®‡§ø, ‡§∏‡•Ç. for ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§ï‡§æ.‡§™‡•ç‡§∞. for ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂etc. The manner of reference is also easy to understand. References to KƒÅvyaprakƒÅ≈õa are usually to theUllƒÅsas, and, where pages are mentioned, they are from the Edition of VƒÅmanƒÅchƒÅrya Zalakikar, third Edition byN.D.Banhatti, (1917). References to the pages of ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï,‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ, ‡§∞‡§∏‡§ó‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞, etc. are to the editions of these workspublished by the Nirnaya Sagara Press, Bombay, throughthe KƒÅvyamƒÅlƒÅ Series. References to metrical works willpresent very little difficulty as passages in them can bereferred to by numbers of stanzas and chapters. Referencesto BhƒÅmaha’s ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞are to the text as published byRao Bahadur K. P. Trivedi in his edition of ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∑‡§£, Bombay Sanskrit Series, No. 65. References to ‡§Ö‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Äand ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø are to ‡§Ö‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø, ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶ and ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ or ‡§Ü‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§ï.

 MIRAJ,

August, 20, 1925.
N. D. BANHATTI.

landmark in the development of the science of poetics. Judging from the tributes paid to him and from the references made to him and to his opinions by ala·πÖkƒÅra-writerswe can say without the least fear of exaggeration that his influence on alank√§ra literature was second to none tillthe time of Mamma·π≠a’s KƒÅvyaprakƒÅ≈õa. It is true thatowing to the great advance effected during the threecenturies that intervened between them and owing to the absorbing genius of Mamma»õa, Udbha·π≠a’s works werethrown rather into the background after Mamma·π≠a’s time. Yet as facts are being brought to light gradually the realstate of things has begun to force itself upon us and we are becoming aware of the fame and popularity that ourauthor once enjoyed. Commensurate with his fame andpopularity the number of his commentators must havebeen large, and from the facts that are now available wecan assert that his work was commented upon by more than three exegetes at least.

As far as our knowledge goes the first commentatorthat Udbha·π≠a had was IndurƒÅja. It does not appear eitherfrom the contents of IndurƒÅja’s Laghuv·πõitti or from anyexternal evidence that Udbha·π≠a had another commentatorbefore IndurƒÅja. After IndurƒÅja we find that one ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§ïis mentioned as having written an ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§ï or ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞. Thecommentary ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä of ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§∞‡§• on Ruyyaka’s ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ statesin more than one place that ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§ïwrote a gloss onUdbhata called ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§ï, and that the ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ himselfgenerally followed the views propounded in ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§ï. (VideKƒÅvyamƒÅlƒÅ edition of‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µpp. 115, 205 etc.) Now Ruyyaka composed his‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µabout A. D. 1150. And relying upon the facts which seem to prove that Ruyyaka was the same person as Ruchaka who mentions‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï as the name of his father we may place‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï a littlebefore A. D. 1150.

Of this ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§ïno MS. has as yet been discovered. But another MS. containing a commentary named ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Éhas been discovered at Kudalur Mana, in Malabarin A.D. 1919‚Äì20. A copy of it has been deposited in the Gov-

INTRODUCTION.

<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1729587220‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ú‡§ø.png"/>

I THE AUTHOR.

From the general chaos and the consequent blindconjectures of many of the modern researchers, some ofthe Kashmirian poets and authors are saved by the greatgenius of Kalha·πáa, and our author is fortunate enough to belong to that category. Kalha·πáa’s RƒÅjatarangi·πáƒ´ containsdistinct mention of one Udbha»õa whom from the authorityof his (Kalhana’s) commentators and from other circumstantial evidence we can definitely identify with theauthor of KƒÅvyƒÅla·πÅkƒÅrasƒÅrasangraha.

(i) His place.

Udbhata was evidently a born Kashmirian as hisname clearly shews.¬π1The name Udbha»õa is one of theclass of names of authors such as Jaiya»õa, Kaiya·π≠a, Alla»õa,Rudra»õa and Mamma»õa who are acknowledged Kashmirians. He was also a resident of Kashmir as he was theSabhƒÅpati of JayƒÅpƒ´·∏ça, one of the kings of Kashmir.¬≤2

(ii) His date.

In the first place we can ascertain with precision thatUdbha»õa came after BhƒÅmaha and preceded √Önandavardhana. Udbha»õa had written a commentary^(33)on BhƒÅmahaand besides, the present work of his contains many distinctadaptations and verbal borrowings from BhƒÅmaha’s KƒÅvyƒÅla·πÖkƒÅra.‚Å¥4√Çnandavardhana pointedly mentionsUdbha»õa in more than one place, and we may concludefrom his manner of referring that Udbhata was regarded

by him as a venerable elderly author within memory ofthe people of those times.^(1)The times of Udbha»õa andƒÄnandavardhana given by RƒÅjatarangi·πáƒ´are perfectlyconsistent with this our conclusion. Udbha»õa belonged tothe reign of JayƒÅpƒ´·∏ça (779‚Äì813 A.D.), and ƒÄnandavardhanaflourished in the reign of Avantivarman (857‚Äì884 A.D.)^(2)Thus there exists a difference of about 40 or 50 years between the careers of both these ƒÄlankƒÅrikas and the dateof the end of Udbha»õa and the birth of ƒÄnandavardhanawould still be much nearer each other. Thus it is quitepossible, Udbha·π≠a might have lived within memory of thepeople of ƒÄnandavardhana’s times.

(iii) Other particulars.

Exceedingly little is known at present about the detailsof the private life of our author; and this is quite naturalwith the vast gulf of more than eleven hundred years between his and our own times. Man lives by his works. But the peculiar misfortune of Udbha»õa was that his workswere enveloped in oblivion before his name,which hadexisted in the works suchas‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂, ‡§∞‡§∏‡§ó‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞ and the like,to remind us of the individual; and until the presentwork, one of his numerous compositions, was discovered about 45 years ago,^(3) we were only wondering at the
*

    *

  1. ‡§Ü‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§® has: - ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§ (‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§É‚Äî p.108). Here ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§É probably indicates that the person or persons thus referred to are remembered as living in the times of the writer. See also the other reference to Udbha·π≠a on p‚Ä¢ 96, ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï.

  2. Kalha·πáa mentions Udbha»õa and

ƒÄ

nandavardhana in bis RƒÅjatarangini thus:‚Äî

‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§£ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡•ã‡§≠‡•Ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø (‡§ú‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•Ä‡§°‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ) ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§É ‡§∏‡§≠‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•• ‡§§‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§É‚Äì‡•™.‡•™‡•Ø‡•´.

‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§ï‡§£‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§É‡•• ‡§§‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§É‚Äì‡•´.‡•©‡•™.

  1. The credit of the find is due to G. B√ºhler who undertook hisfamous tour in Kashmir in 1875, and brought to light many valuableworks on poetry, rhetorics and history of Kashmir. For further information see his Report on the tour to Kashmir, J. B. B. R. A. S. Extra No. of 1877.

importance given to his name and the school of thought installed by him, by such writers as ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ü, ‡§ú‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§•and others. No mention of his parentage, his teachers, his friends or even his own name exists in this work, and without the commentary of IndurƒÅja we could not have learnt that the work belonged to the famous ƒÄla·πÖkƒÅrika Udbha·π≠a. The only reliable information about the life and activities of Udbha»õa is what is given to us by Kalha·πáa in his RƒÅjatara·πÖgi·πáƒ´

. Kalha·πáa thus mentions Udbha·π≠a :‚Äî

‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§£ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡•ã‡§≠‡•Ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø (‡§ú‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•Ä‡§°‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø) ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§É ‡§∏‡§≠‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡••
‚Äî

RƒÅjatara·πÖgi·πáƒ´, IV. 495.

From this we learn that Bha·π≠·π≠a Udbhata was the SabhƒÅpati or the Head of the assembly of Pandits, at the court of the Kashmirian king JayƒÅpƒ´

·∏ça. It appears from his present work that he was a profound grammarian. A hundred thousand DinƒÅras per day seem to be too exhorbitant a tax on the treasury of the king even for those days of unbounded wealth. Possibly Udbhata was not going to the court of the king every day but once in many days or months; and the remuneration of Laksha DinƒÅras probably pertained to the day when he attended the court.

Whatever the case might be, we need not at this time either envy or ridicule the learned man and the author for being the recipient of such a gift. In this connection we can only overlook the unjustifiable remarks made by B√ºhler upon Udbhata. He says:‚Äî“The oldest text books on ala·πÖkƒÅra, those of BhƒÅmaha’ and Bha·π≠·π≠anƒÅyaka, have been lost, but a great number are still extant, the earliest of which belong to the times of King JayƒÅpƒ´

·∏ça, 779-813 A. D. One of these, the Ala·πÖkarƒÅ≈õƒÅstra of Bha·π≠·π≠a Udbha»õa, I found, together with a commentary
*
*

1. The text of BhƒÅmaha has now been discovered, and we find it printed as an appendix to Prat

ƒÅ

parudraya≈õobh≈´

shana, a modern work on poetics, edited with copious notes and introduction by Rao Bahadur K. P. Trivedi, B. A., in the Bomhay Sanskrit series, No. LXV.

of Pratƒ´hƒÅra IndurƒÅja, in Jesalmir. Of this Bha·π≠·π≠odbha»õa Kalha·πáa says that he was JayƒÅpƒ´·∏ça’s SabhƒÅpati, or ChiefPa·πá·∏çit, and that he was paid daily a lakh of Dƒ´nƒÅras. It is to be regretted that the recipient of such munificentpay did not write a more extensive book, and did not giveus extracts from contemporaneous poets. He has onlycomposed a short treatise on AlankƒÅras or ornaments to beused in poetry, and most egotistically takes his examplesfrom his own work, a KumƒÅrasambhava”. It was not thefault of Udbha»õa if his works did not survive till the ageof our modern researcher; still less was it his fault if theresearcher had remained blind to IndurƒÅja’sstatement thatUdbhata had written ‘a gloss on BhƒÅmaha’ or even if afterreading the statement, had refused to admit the ‘Gloss on BhƒÅmaha’ as a ‘book’. Udbha·π≠a Bha·π≠·π≠a certainly does notdeserve such a mention in a ridiculous tone if he did notdream in his time that his insertion of examples fromcontemporaneous poets would prove of great value to theresearchers that were destined, eleven hundred years later, to wield the fate of writers like him in their hands. Itwas the practice of very many writers on poetics to givetheir own verses as illustrations. Da·πá·∏çin, BhƒÅmaha, Rudra»õa, JagannƒÅtha and many others have done the same more or less. Nay, the great ƒÄla·πÖkƒÅrika Poets seemedeven to think it a matter of pride to have been able togive examples of their own composition in illustration of the several items of poetics.¬π

II WORKS OF UDBHATA.

We know that Udbha»õa was the author of at least threeworks including the present one, the other two works whichare not available at present, being (1) a commentary onBhƒÅmaha’s work, and (2) a poem named KumƒÅrasambhava.
*

    *
  1. See Jagann

ƒÅ

tha’s RasagangƒÅdhara ‚Äîp. 2.

‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§®‡•Ç‡§§‡§®‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç
‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§É
‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡§®‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•É‡§ó‡•á‡§£‡••

For this information we are indebted to IndurƒÅja whosays in one place of his commentary, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡•á ‡§ö ‡§≠‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡§£‡•á¬π ‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü‡•á‡§® ‡§è‡§ï‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§•‡•á‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§É5and at anotherplace, ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§™‡§∞‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡§µ‡•à‡§ï‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§£‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§É6‡•§

About BhƒÅmahavivara·πáa we do not know anything as far as our present knowledge goes. The numerousreferences to Udbha»õa occurring in various works on Ala·πÖkƒÅra allude sometimes to such subjects as arenot at all included in KƒÅvyƒÅla·πÖkƒÅrasƒÅrasangraha. Itis possible that they might be referring to the ‘Glosson BhƒÅmaha or perhaps to some other great work on Ala·πÖkƒÅra that Udbha·π≠a might have composed. Sometimesvery curious thing can be seen in some modern works: passages discussing the opinions of ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ and othersare at times seriously quoted and fathered upon Udbha»õa. For example, Rasaga·πÖgƒÅdhara says‚Äì ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É‡•§ “‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§∞‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø ‡§è‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ã‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§® ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡•á‡§§ …….‡§® ‡§ö

‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å‡§ü‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡•ã‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§ …… ……‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É‡•§“‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡•§7Here Uabha·π≠a is described as passing opinion on ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞’s (‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ü’s) views! Of course such quoted passages cannotbe seriously considered. But the references of ƒÄnandavardhana, such as the one cited above in a foot note, or ofRuyyaka such as ‡§á‡§π ‡§π‡§ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ç‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á8or ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç
*

    *

1. It is not necessary to conclude that the name of the commentaryitself was ‡§≠‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡§£. ‡§≠‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡§£ more probably means only a gloss onBhƒÅmaha’s work**.**

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∂‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç8point to the fact that Udbha·π≠a wasa standard author on Ala·πÖkƒÅra and had written someala·πÖkƒÅra works besides the present one. For the subjectsreferred to in the above passages are foriegn to this treatise.

The poem KumƒÅrasambhava which was composedby Udbha»õa evidently contained the same theme thatmakes the story of the KumƒÅrasambhava of KƒÅlidƒÅsa. Andprobably this was the reason why it was altogether lostto Sanskrit Literature except the fragment that exists inthe shape of the examples of KƒÅvyƒÅla·πÅkƒÅrasƒÅrasangraha.Although it is no wonder that the KumƒÅrasambhava ofUdbha»õa could not hold out for long against the established eminence of the poem of the Prince of poets, still hispoetry is not of a low order and if its subject were not thesame as that of KƒÅlidƒÅsa’s KumƒÅrasambhava it wouldsurely have held its own upto this time. The verses includedin the present work as examples are 94 and they are probab.ly one Sarga of the whole poem as the thread of the narrative goes on fairly unbroken from beginning to end. Butsometimes the natural order of verses seems to be changed. Thus the natural position of the 8th9verse seems to beafter the 5th.10It is standing without a verb in its present position. The 33rd11verse should have its natural placeafter the 31st12,for the 32nd13verse contains the exclamationof the pt and not the thoughts of ≈öiva as is required bythe 33rdverse.‚Å∑A little gap is also occasionally experiencedbetween the meanings of two verses. Butthat is quite natural in a narrative specially composed toillustrate all figures in a settled order. Notwithstandingthis, there is a great beauty in the description and the style which makes it a great pleasure to read the poem even
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

  1. Idem, p. 33. See appendix II for the verses given in the order in which they exist in the text.

more than once. And one really cannot but regret thefate of such a beautiful poem condemned to rest in oblivionfor no defect of its own.

The substance of the story contained in these 94 versesis as follows:‚ÄîAfter [burning cupid] the God ≈öiva passedhis time leisurely in a valley of the HimƒÅlayas (Stanzas 1-2). But when the autumnal season (‡§∂‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç) appeared his mind again became perturbed by passion and he began tothink about PƒÅrvatƒ´(St. 3-31). Being thus agitated he cameto Parvati in the guise of a celibate (‡§¨‡§ü‡•Å) (St. 32-35). Hesaw Parvati performing hard penance, and yet shiningbeautiful in that condition (St. 37-44). While he was thusobserving and musing on the beauty and lustre of Parvatihe got intensely excited and was on the verge of committing a rash act (St. 45-58). But he appeased himself intime and addressed Parvati thus:‚Äî ‚ÄúYou are the daughterof the glorious Himalaya and yourself are beautifulbeyond comparison (St. 59-68); such hard penance isnot proper for you and if you are performing it with the desire of getting a wooer, it is quite needless (St. 69-79); for, on account of your beauty every youth is bound downto your feet as a slave, ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á‡§£ ‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§É ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã ‡§π‡§ø ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§É. EvenGod Vish·πáu will abandon Lakshmi and come down foryour hand (St. 80-91). Therefore abandon this ascetic lifeand have a home for yourself with any fortunate youth asyour mate, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§®‡•ã‡§´‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú ‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§π‡§ø‡•§ ‡§â‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•á‡••‚Äù

III. THE KƒÄVYƒÄLA·πÑKƒÄRA-SƒÄRA-SA·πÑGRAHA.

** **This work is a treatise on the figures of poetry belonging to word and sense. In all 41 ala·πÖkƒÅras are accorded treatment and these 41 are divided into 6 groups. Neither the groups nor the whole order of enumerationseem to follow any scientific principle. The order ofthe ala·πÖkƒÅras and their grouping generally followBhƒÅmaha. The definitions are also many a time borrowed, sometimes completely and sometimes with a slightchange, from BhƒÅmaha. The definitions of ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§æ, the

first variety of ‡§Ö‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø, ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§∏‡§π‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø, ‡§∏‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π and ‡§Ö‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø are bodily taken from BhƒÅmaha. The definitions of ‡§Ü‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§™, ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ,‡§Ö‡§™‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡§ø,‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß and ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ are accepted with some change. Half portions of the definitions of ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ and ‡§∞‡§∏‡§µ‡§§‡•ç arealso taken from BhƒÅmaha. But even so muchborrowingcannot overshadow the original nature of Udbhata’s work.His originality and acuteness are seen even in the slightalterations he makes in BhƒÅmaha’s originals.¬π In thedefinitions which he has not taken from BhƒÅmaha hisgenius is fully brought out, for even Mamma·π≠a has manytimes thought it fit toaccept the ideas and structurescreated by Udbha·π≠a. Udbha·π≠a only accepts BhƒÅmaha’sversion where he agrees with him, and no one will findfault with him if he has done so instead of casting thesame definition in words different from those of BhƒÅmaha.If his own views are the same as those of BhƒÅmaha on aparticular ala≈àkƒÅra, a straight-forward borrowing fromsuch a great author as BhƒÅmaha was perhaps better thancomposing the definition in his own words which wasbound to be similar in meaning with that of the original. When the definition of Bhamaha does not fit in with hismore advanced views he casts it aside and brings out hisown definition which would even match with that ofMamma»õa in accuracy.

The high ability and the independence of thought ofUdbha·π≠a in theprovince of Ala·πÖkƒÅra is displayed in onemore way. He is not at all a slavish follower of BhƒÅmahaor any other old ƒÅla·πÖkƒÅrika. He has rejected some ala·πÖkƒÅras that are treated by BhƒÅmaha, as he did not think itfit to treat them as separate ala·πÖkƒÅras. Thus he does notat all mention the ala·πÖkƒÅras ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ï,‡§Ö‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡§µ (‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶),‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ïand ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§µwhich are defined and illustrated inBhƒÅmaha’s K√§vyƒÅla·πÖkƒÅra. On the other hand he adds someala·πÖkƒÅras of his own to the established list of ala·πÖkƒÅrasand they are invariably accepted after him by all writers on

     ***

1.For example, see the definition of ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§∂‡§∏‡§æ.By putting thesingle wordhe has excellently brought out the chief characteristic of the alankara which was absent in Bhamaha’s definition

.

rhetorics. According to our knowledge Udbha·π≠a is thefirst writer to include ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏,‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å and ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§ inthe generally accepted list of ala·πÖkƒÅras. Not only in thework of BhƒÅmaha but in those of Da·πá·∏çin, VƒÅmana andother old writers no trace is found of these figures. Theproper examples of‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§ and ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ówere inserted undersome other ala·πÖkƒÅras and the creation of such alankaras as‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó and ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§, especially of ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§, did not occur to any one. We are thus led to the conclusion that Udbhatafirst brought these ala·πÖk√§ras into existence. They were of course accepted and placed among important ala·πÖkƒÅrasby later writers.

IV. UDBHATA’S POSITION IN ALA·πÑ

KƒÄRA LITERATURE.

Rhetorics and poetics as a science was earlydeveloped in Kashmir, and different stages in its development are illustrated clearly in the works of differentauthors. BhƒÅmaha was a KƒÅ≈õmiraka and he is the oldestextant author among them to write on Ala·πÖkara. Soon afterhim among the extant writers comes Udbhata at the endof the eighth century and somewhere about this timemust have appeared the author of ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ω. After himcame the celebrated ƒÄnandavardhana, the author ofDhvanƒÅyloka, in the latter half of the ninth century.Something like 80 years later, in the latter half of thetenth century, was the time of our commentator IndurƒÅja; and slightly anterior to IndurƒÅja must havelived Rudrata¬πthe author of KƒÅvyƒÅla·πÖkƒÅra and Mukula
*

    *

1. The only terminus ad quem to Rudrata’s date was supposed tobe the middle of the eleventh century as his commentator NamisƒÅdhuhad written his comment in A.D.1069 But we can now say with certainty that he appeared before Induraja whose time we have settled tobe about A.D.970 We can also have a probable estimation of theterminus a quo of his date. IndurƒÅja now and then quotes him without name And it is the habit of IndurƒÅja to quote the recent authorsof his time without name. Also DhvanyƒÅ

lokadoes not contain a single

the author of AbhidhƒÅv·πõittimƒÅt·πõikƒÅ. After IndurƒÅja cameAbhinavagupta, the author of the gloss Lochana onDhvanyƒÅloka, for he mentions his own date in some of hisworks, which is the end of the 10th century A.D. After thiscame Mahimabha·π≠·π≠a, Kshemendra, Ruyyaka and finallyMammata. This list is, we believe, fairly complete as faras the important Kashmirian writers on AlankƒÅra areconcerned; and if we add a few names such as Dandin, VƒÅmana, BhojarƒÅja, Hemachandra and VƒÅgbha»õa (author of VƒÅgbha·π≠ƒÅlankƒÅra) we shall have completed a roughsurvey of all authors on poetics upto the time of Mamma·π≠a.

The Kashmirian authors have been mentioned separately in the above list to shew the extent to which theScience of poetics or Ala·πÖkƒÅra≈õƒÅstra was early developedby the KƒÅ≈õmƒ´rakas. Not only was the development early and extensive but its direction and trend also seem to bedifferent from the views and theories of ƒÅlankƒÅrikas inthe rest of India. If we compare the works of Dandin,VƒÅmana, Bhoja and VƒÅgbha»õa on the one hand with those
*

    *

verse either taken as quotation or otherwise from Rudrata. This andthe general treatment of the subject in the work which is of a moderntype indicates that the work must have been composed a little afterƒÄnandavardhana and a little before IndurƒÅja. Now the time of ƒÄnandavardhana is about A. D. 885-910. Therefore, unless any con tradictory evidence comes forth, we can place Rudra»õa in the interval between the two limits viz. A. D. 900 and 970.

  1. Ke≈õavami≈õra of Ala·πÖkƒÅra≈õekhara, VƒÅgbha»õa of KƒÅvyƒÅnu≈õƒÅsanaand some others have not been included in the above enumeration asthey probably come after Mamma

·π≠

a. They are probably non-KƒÅshmƒ´rians. Even if they be KƒÅshmirians they would not affect our conclusions in any way. Some say that VƒÅmana of KƒÅvyƒÅla·πÅkƒÅras≈´tra was aKƒÅshmirian, but we do not think so. At least it is quite certain that hisviews are not similar to those of BhƒÅmaha, Udbha

·π≠

a and others who areaccepted KƒÅshmirians. We are not so much concerned with his actual place of living as we are with the trend of views that he displays in hiswork.

of BhƒÅmaha, Udbha·π≠a and Ruyyaka on the other, there willbe found many important and inherent diversities in thesetwo groups. Da·πá·∏çin and his followers give supremeprominence to Gu·πáas which are ten according to them¬π, or even more according to Bhoja. Doshas or faults in theiropinion are the opposites of Gunas. And Rƒ´ti or style isalso admitted by them as an essential factor of poetry¬≤. They admit the alankƒÅras Hetu, S≈´kshma and Le≈õa. All these peculiarities exist in the works of these authorsirrespective of time; and all these are scrupulously avoided by all Kashmirians, even by the old author BhƒÅmaha. BhƒÅmaha especially decries the distinctions between Vaidarbhƒ´and Gau·∏çƒ´Rƒ´ti’s, has only three Gu·πáas veryscantily treated and does not admit Hetu, S≈´kshma and Le

≈ö

a into his list of ala·πÖkƒÅras¬≥. All other KƒÅshmirian ƒÅlankƒÅ‚Äì

rikas follow the same path and even Ruyyaka of Ala·πÖkarƒÅsarvasva who has treated more than 80 ala·πÖkƒÅras has notthought fit to accept Hetu¬πand Le≈õa. This, we think, sufficiently establishes the diversity between the twoschools, one of KƒÅ≈õmƒ´rakas and the otherof Vaidarbhas(if we may so call it) of Da·πá·∏çin, Bhoja and others.¬≤ Theepithets new and old would be quite inappropriate forthese schools, as developments of both the systems weregoing on on their own lines up to the time of Mamma»õa.

It is needless to dilate upon the development andhistory of the Kashmirian and the Vaidarbha schools inAla·πÖkƒÅra Literature, as it is not germane to our subjectunder discussion. Even without reference to the Kashmirian or non-Kashmirian nature of his views one can clearlysee from the contents of his work that Udbha·π≠a was thelineal descendant of the thought-system of BhƒÅmaha onthe one hand and the precursor of Mamma·π≠a in many important points of principle and method on the other. In thisway it can be shown-and we hope we have sufficientlyshown it in our Notes-that he holds a very importantposition in the line of authors which began with BhƒÅmahaand terminated with Mamma·π≠a. As all these authors in the thoughtsystem promulgated by BhƒÅmaha kashmirianswe may very well call the school of thought whichthey formed the Kashmirian School ofƒÄla·πÖkƒÅrikas. Thus from the inherent nature of his work and not from anycircumstantial evidence it can be ascertained that Udbhataoccupies an important place in the Kashmirian School.

We have already pointed out that Da·πá·∏çin, VƒÅmana, Bhoja and others of their type differ as a class from theKashmirian writers such as BhƒÅmaha, Udbha·π≠a, Ruyyakaand Mamma·π≠a. Many more minor yet important differencesexist between the two groups which in our opinion go toprove the divergence between the Kashmirians and the
*

    *

  1. We must always bear in mind that the ala·πÖkƒÅra ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Åof Da·πá·∏çin and others is not the same as the ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó or ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å of the Kashmirians.

non-Kashmirians. The whole matter is worth a detailedtreatment but there is no occasion for it here.¬π

The whole Kashmirian school of ƒÄla·πÖkƒÅrikas initself seems to have undergone a great change and development. If we compare the work of BhƒÅmaha with that ofMamma·π≠a we find that both have essentially different kindsof treatment of the science of poetics. Both the style andmethod have changed and the views have undergone a greatrevolution. The new school of thought which arose andspread only in Kashmir was started or promulgated by theauthor of DhvanikƒÅrikƒÅs who must have lived some time before Anandavardhana. The special characteristic of thisnew school was the Dhvani theory. The prominence ofDhvani established with much force by DhvanikƒÅra andƒÄnandavardhana was afterwards disputed or even altogetherthrown over by some writers.¬≤ Along with this discussionand the consequent development of ideas, a reform was
*

    *

  1. If all that is said above is accepted, it would also removethe reasons by which some are put into puzzle about the mutual chronological relations of Da·πá·∏çin and BhƒÅmaha. In many places, Da·πá·∏çin in hisKƒÅvyƒÅdar≈õa seems to criticise the views of Bhamaha, while BhƒÅmahaalso decries in his work some opinions which are exactly the opinionsheld by Da·πá·∏çin. If we accept the view that both were criticizing thetenets of the schools represented by each other and not of individualsall puzzle will be solved.

  2. IndurƒÅja (and perhaps Udbha·π≠a) was probably one who disputedthe supremacy of Dhvani. He holds that Dhvani is the beautifier ofVƒÅchya Artha and is therefore to be included in ala·πÖkƒÅras. Dhvani, therefore, according to IndurƒÅja need not be recognised as the allimportant element in poetry. We are not certain that Udbhata knewthe theory, for we cannot settle whether DhvanikƒÅra preceded orfollowed Udbha·π≠a. Considered independently, his work contains noindication that he was aware of at all. IndurƒÅjaof course interpretshis silence on ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§ø in a different way. He says that: Udbha»õa did nottreat of‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§ø because he thought it altogether included in the alankƒÅras that he had treated of. But evidently this is an attempt of fathering his own views about ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§øupon Udbha·π≠a.

going on in the notions about ala·πÖkƒÅras also¬π. Thesomewhat loose descriptions of BhƒÅmaha were replaced byaccurate and scientific definitions and newer ala·πÖkƒÅraswere brought into existence as more minute discernmentprevailed. Till up to the time of Mamma·π≠a the ala·πÖkƒÅras came up to about seventy and even more; and the tendencyof Mamma·π≠a is seen to diminish the number of ala·πÖkƒÅrasalready growing too unwieldy.

We have unfortunately no means at present to knowUdbha·π≠a’s views about Dhvani theory. But in the development of ala·πÖkƒÅras Udbhata’s position is very clear. He forms the necessary link between the position ofBhƒÅmaha and the position of Mamma·π≠a. While in someplaces Udbha·π≠a accepts verbatim the definitions ofBhƒÅmaha, in others he creates new ideas and builds up hisown definitions upon them which have later become thebasis of the treatment of Mamma·π≠a. The whole scientifictreatment of UpamƒÅthat is put forth by Udbha·π≠a is whollytaken up and assimilated by Mamma·π≠a in his work. Atisayokti, Utpreksh√§ and many other ala·πÖkƒÅras have beentreated by Udbha·π≠a in such a way as to prove a basis tothe treatment of Ruyyaka and Mamma·π≠a. Of courseMammata does not take anything verbally from Udbhataor any other writer but his indebtedness to Udbha·π≠a canbe seen in the above ala·πÖkƒÅras and others if the treatmentand divisions of both are compared carefully with eachother.¬≤ The introduction of KƒÅvyahetu and D·πõish·π≠ƒÅnta isan important feature of Udbhata’s work and we have already adverted to it before.

We have not the whole system of Udbha·π≠a’s viewsbefore us, as probably a small piece of his whole work

has reached us. But he was no doubt a very importantwriter in the whole Kashmirian system of ƒÅla·πÖkƒÅrikas. All authors including ƒÄnandavardhana, Abhinavagupta, Ruyyaka and Mamma»õa refer to him with great respect.He must have originated a school of thought that had somevery peculiar tenets of its own. This is clear from thefrequent references occurring in very many works, as‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§É, ‡§î‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü‡§æ‡§É, ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡§É ete¬π.As many of thepeculiarities as could be gathered from the references made to them are given here:‚Äî

(1) Udbha·π≠a and his followers considered that gu·πáasand ala·πÖkƒÅras were essentially of the same nature, bothbeing the inherent beautifiers of poetry. The only differencethat is made between gu·πáas and ala·πÖkƒÅras is because theybelong to different elements of poetry. The gu·πáas belongboth to word (‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶) and sense (‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•) together, while theala·πÖkƒÅras belong either to ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶(e.g. AnuprƒÅsa, Yamakaetc.) or to ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•(e.g.UpamƒÅ, UtprekshƒÅ etc.) severally, and not to both of them together. This is the only reasonwhy gu·πáas and ala·πÖkƒÅras should be distinguished fromeach other, otherwise they are all the same.

(2) The ala·πÖkƒÅras UpamƒÅ, UtprekshƒÅ etc. exist evenwhen they are known by suggested sense as well as whenthey are expressed. Mamma·π≠a and others hold thatala·πÖkƒÅras only belong to VƒÅchya or expressed sense; all suggestion if prominent is called Dhvani.

(3) If ≈ölesha and some other ala·πÖkƒÅra exist together, importance is to be given to ≈ölesha and the otherala·πÖkƒÅra is to be considered subordinate.¬≤

(4) The suggested sense is altogether included in theala·πÖkƒÅras as it is only a beautifier of the VƒÅchya sense and

    *

V. THE COMMENTATOR INDURƒÄJA.

IndurƒÅja, the author of the Laghuv·πõitti, is also an important personage in the history of Ala·πÖkƒÅra Literature. He was connected with two other well known writers inthe field of .Ala·πÖkƒÅra. As a pupil he was related toMukula¬≤ the author of AbhidhƒÅv·πõittimƒÅt·πõikƒÅ. Mukula inthe last KƒÅrikƒÅ of his AbhidhƒÅv·πõittimƒÅt·πõikƒÅ mentionsKalla·π≠a as the name of his father. Now Kalha·πáa in hisRƒÅjatarangi·πáƒ´ mentions one Kallata as a ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç‡§∑living in the reign of Avantivarman:‚Äî

‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§É‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ü‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§Æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡••
RƒÅjatara·πÖgi·πái‚ÄìV.66.

Avantivarman’s reign lasted from A. D. 857 to 884Assuming that this Kallata is the same as the father ofMukula we may fix upon the end of the 9th and the beginning of the 10th century as the date of Mukula. HenceMukula’s pupil IndurƒÅja may fairly be assigned to a timelittle later than that of Mukula i. e. circa A.D.950

As a teacher (upƒÅdhyƒÅya) IndurƒÅja was connectedwith Abhinavagupta the commentator of DhvanyƒÅloka, asAbhinavagupta himself states in the beginning of his Locana:‚Äî

*

  1. It is needless to cite here all the references from which the above gist is drawn.

  2. IndurƒÅja himself at the beginning of his Laghuvritti says:‚Äî‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§ß‡§ø‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§É‡•• At the end also he has a very beautiful verse on Mukula:‚Äî

‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡§ï‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ã‡§É ‡§∂‡•å‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§¨‡•ç‡§ú‡§≠‡•É‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡•å‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§¨‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§¨‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§§‡•ç
‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Å‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡•å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§£‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§É‡••

‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§¨‡•ç‡§ú‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã
‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•ã‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡§µ‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•ã‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡§£‡§®‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å‡§ü‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ-
‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§≤‡•ã‡§ö‡§®‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡••
‚Äî DhvanyƒÅlokalochana, P. 1.

In the body of his Lochana also, he says, in severalplaces, when quoting a verse of IndurƒÅja,‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ

‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø.From this also we can arrive at the date of IndurƒÅja, for Abhinavagupta’s date is known with certainty. Abhinavagupta has affixed dates to some of his works;one of them was composed, he says, in A.D. 991 andanother in A.D.1014 Thus we can safely assign Abhinavagupta to A.D., 980-1020 and consequently IndurƒÅja’s time can be stated to be about A.D. 950-990.

But how can we say that IndurƒÅja, the author of theLaghuv·πõitti, was the same as the IndurƒÅja, the teacher ofAbhinavagupta? There might have been two differentpersonages of the name of IndurƒÅja. The times of raising such objections have now passed,¬πbut still some corroborative evidence might be adduced for our conclusion.
*
*

1. While the work is passing through the press we observe, however, that in his recently published essay on ‚ÄúThe History of Ala·πÖ

kƒÅraLiterature,‚Äùprefixed as an Introduction to the Second Edition (1923) ofhis ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§£, Mr. P.V. Kano expresses his opinion that ‚Äúthough ‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§úand ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§úwere both of them well versed in Ala·πÖkara ≈öƒÅstra andflourished almost about the same time, they must be regarded as distinct.‚Äù The facts of the case do not, it seems to us, warrant such a conclusion.We fail to see how the fact that IndurƒÅja differed from the views ofthe author of DhvanyƒÅloka would prevent him from explaining thatwork to his pupil. Even at this date we observe a staunch Vaishnava, follower of Dvaita VedƒÅnta, explaining to his pupil tenets of AdvaitaVedƒÅnta which he personally does not approve of. According to our oldideas the acharya or preceptor is regarded as ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç‡§ó‡§§and is expected to teach every thing that the pupil has a craving to learn. Besides onemust bear in mind that Abhinavagupta had more teachers than one, andwhen he only says ‘‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡§É’,‘‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§É’,etc. without mentioning thename of the teacher it is quite possible that some teacher other than IndurƒÅja might have been meant.

(1) We have seen that ƒÄnandavardhana lived aboutA.D.900. IndurƒÅja quotes without name more than oneverse of the authorship of ƒÄnandavardhana.¬πIt seemsto be the habit of IndurƒÅja to give the name of a remoteauthor. He always quotes without names from authorsthat were quite recent in his time. Verses of Rudra·π≠a andmany other verses which we have not been able to trace upto any extant writer, are quoted in a similar way withoutname. He quotes the names of BhƒÅmaha, VƒÅmana, Da·πá·∏çin, Amaruka, but not of Rudra·π≠a, ƒÄnandavardhana and thelike. This clearly shews that ƒÄnandavardhana was arecent author when IndurƒÅja lived.

(2) IndurƒÅja, the teacher of Abhinavagupta, was alsoa poet and anƒÅla·πÖ

kƒÅrika, and lived at the same time andin the same place as IndurƒÅja, the author of theLaghuv·πõitti, therefore it is probable he may be identical with the author of the Laghuv·πõitti.

Thus, we think, it is established that IndurƒÅja lived about A.D. 940-990.

Abhinavagupta also tells us something about the parentage of IndurƒÅja. He has written a gloss on BhagavadgitƒÅand at the end of it he tells us that IndurƒÅja’s fatherwas Bh≈´tirƒÅja and his grandfather was Sauchuka, ofKƒÅtyƒÅyana gotra.

That is all that we can at present know or determinewith any amount of certainty about IndurƒÅja. The rest isbound to be mere guess, or at the most, probable inferencesfrom the facts available.

We can very readily believe that IndurƒÅja was aKƒÅshmƒ´raka. His own work and his relations with otherƒÅla·πÖkƒÅrikas before and after his time almost make it
*
*

  1. One verse is: ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§ï‡§∂‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‚Äî etc. (Vide p. 88 of the text). This verse occurs on p. 101 of ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ïwhere the author distinctly owns theverse as is his own thus:‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•à‡§µ‡•§ ‘‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§ï‡§∂‡§∞‡§£etc.‘Another verse is‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§etc.(vide p. 87 of the text).Thisis also owned in ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ïat p. 110 in a similar way.

certain that he lived in Kashmir. His own work showsthat he had a very intimate acquaintance with all Kashmirian works on ala·πÖkƒÅra and his views are nothing ifthey are not of a Kashmirian type. Yet we must solve the difficulty presented by the epithet Kau·πÖka·πáa which IndurƒÅja has himself appended to his name before we can callhim a native of Kashmir. There may be three possibleconjectures‚Äî

  1. Ku·πÖka·πáa (‡§ï‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§£) might be the name of his fatheror some remote ancestor, so that Kau·πÖka·πáa may mean ‘a son or descendent of Ku·πÖka·πáa.’

  2. Ku·πÖka·πáa or Ko·πÖka·πáa might be a town or a province somewhere in or near Kashmir and IndurƒÅja mustbe an inhabitant of that place.

  3. Ko·πÖka·πáa must be the same province that is atpresent styled by the same name. Thus Ko·πÖka·πáa maymean the modern coastal districts of Kolaba and Ratnagiri, south of Bombay.

If we accept Abhinavagupta’s information, and wecannot doubt it, then we must reject the supposition thatKu·πÖka·πáa was the name of IndurƒÅja’s father. And itis extremely improbable that IndurƒÅja might be referringto any of his remote ancestors by the word Kau·πÖka·πáa. No geographical or other data are available that wouldsupport our second supposition. The third supposition, that Ko·πÖka·πáa of modern times must be the countryto which IndurƒÅjabelonged, seems also to be beyond allprobability. A person, native of the southwest coast ofIndia, intimately connected with several people of aprovince a thousand and more miles apart, seems a quiteimpossible picture for those olden times.

But although we may be unwilling to believe thatIndurƒÅja was a native and resident of the coastal districts called Ko·πÖkan we may still suppose that his familyhad come from Ko·πÖkan to be naturalised in Kashmirin bygone times. His case might be compared withthat of the Ko·πÖka·πáastha Brahmans of our times who

while still calling themselves Ko·πÖka·πáasthas (i.e.‡§ï‡•å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§£‡§æ‡§É) have left all traces of their connection with Ko·πÖkan andhave become naturalised residents of MahƒÅrƒÅsh·π≠ra andother Indian provinces for several generations. That IndurƒÅja’s forefathers might have migrated from Ko·πÖkanto Kashmir is rendered probable by the available evidencethat a general intercourse was kept up between these provinces in those times. The following verses in the poemof a Kashmirian poet (‡§Æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ñ) contain the description of anambassador named ‡§§‡•á‡§ú‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§† despatched by ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø, the kingof Ko·πÖkan, to Kashmir in the 12th century:‚Äî

‡§µ‡§ö‡•ã‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§®‡•Å‡§¶‡•á ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•Å‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡•ã‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡••
‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§¶‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡•á‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§ø‡§ò‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ò‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§ò‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ï‡•ã‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§£‡•á (‡§®‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§£‡•á) ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É‡••
‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡•á‡§ú‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡•á‡§®………etc.
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ of ‡§Æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ñ, 25, 109 to 111.

Thus IndurƒÅja, although a Kashmirian to all intentsand purposes might very well call himself a Kau·πÖka·πáa.

IndurƒÅja has also prefixed the epithet ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§π‡§æ‡§∞to hisname. It may mean ’the holder of a title of that name‚Äôor ’the recipient of a freehold such as ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§æ‡§∞’. It may even be connected with PratihƒÅra, the particular syllables inthe SƒÅma-hymns which the Pratihart·πõi14has to sing. IndurƒÅja was perhaps a follower of the SƒÅma-Veda.

The verses which Abhinavagupta has quoted as belonging to IndurƒÅja and the two verses ascribedBha·π≠·π≠endurƒÅja in Kshemendra’s Auchitya-vichƒÅra-charchƒÅand some other works are given in Appendix

II.

VI. THE LAGHUVRITTI.

The Laghuv·πõitti of IndurƒÅja is a very valuable andlearned commentary.

Its special elegances are:

(i) The peculiar and charming method of explaining the KƒÅrikƒÅs.

(ii) The flowing, argumentative and terse yet lucid style.

IndurƒÅja’s way of explaining KƒÅrikƒÅs is his speciality. He first takes one of the epithets in theKƒÅrikƒÅ as the primary definition and begins to shew how all other epithets are necessary to have a completedefinition of the ala·πÖkara in question. For example, seethe vritti on the definitions of ≈ölish·π≠a, UtprekshƒÅ, Sandeha,and Sa·πÖkara.
IndurƒÅja’s style is terse yet it is not at all difficultto an accustomed reader of Sanskrit commentaries. It is not elliptic as that of Mamma»õa.

Udbha·π≠a’s KƒÅvyƒÅla·πÖkƒÅrasƒÅrasa·πÖgraha with the commentary of IndurƒÅja is a very valuable work. The accurate yet easy definitions of Udbha·π≠a, the learned disquisitions of IndurƒÅja upon them and the beautiful examples exactly fitting in with the bearing of the KƒÅrikƒÅs, forms a combination at once very useful andengaging. The ala·πÖkƒÅras treated are few and prominent and there are no elaborate and minute divisions madeof them as is the tendency of works on Ala·πÖkƒÅra laterthan Mamma·π≠a. The work would therefore be a veryhandy and useful manual to a modern student of Ala·πÖkƒÅra who would perhaps equally dislike the cumbrousand unwieldy dissertations of modern writers on the onehand, and the loose and primary treatment of very old authors on the other.

VII. OTHER COMMENTARIES ON THE KƒÄ

VYƒÄLA·πÑKARA-S

ƒÄ

RA-SA·πÑGRAHA.

Udbha·π≠a himself was a commentator as we have seenabove. He had written a gloss on BhƒÅmaha’s KƒÅvyƒÅla·πÖkƒÅra. But his original and creative genius could not besatisfied with having commented upon others views merely; so he wrote the present work which has since become a

landmark in the development of the science of poetics. Judging from the tributes paid to him and from the references made to him and to his opinions by ala·πÖkƒÅra-writers we can say without the least fear of exaggeration that his influence on ala·πÖkƒÅra literature was second to none till the time of Mamma·π≠a’s KƒÅvyaprakƒÅ≈õa. It is true that owing to the great advance effected during the three centuries that intervened between them and owing to the absorbing genius of Mamma·π≠a, Udbha·π≠a’s works were thrown rather into the background after Mamma·π≠a’s time. Yet as facts are being brought to light gradually the real state of things has begun to force itself upon us and we are becoming aware of the fame and popularity that our author once enjoyed. Commensurate with his fame and popularity the number of his commentators must have been large, and from the facts that are now available we can assert that his work was commented upon by more than three exegetes at least.

As far as our knowledge goes the first commentator that Udbha·π≠a had was IndurƒÅja. It does not appear either from the contents of IndurƒÅja’s Laghuv·πõitti or from any external evidence that Udbha·π≠a had another commentator before IndurƒÅja. After IndurƒÅja we find that one ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§ïis mentioned as having written an ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§ï or ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞. commentary ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä of ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§∞‡§• on Ruyyaka’s ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ states in more than one place that ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§ïwrote a gloss on Udbha·π≠a called ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§ï, and that the ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ himself generally followed the views propounded in ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§ï(Vide KƒÅvyamƒÅlƒÅ edition of ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µpp.115, 205 e.t.c) NowRuyyaka composed his ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ about A.D.1150etc.) And relying upon the facts which seem to prove that Ruyyaka was the same person as Ruchaka who mentions ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï as the name of his father we may place ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§ïa little before A.D.1150.

Of this ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§ïno MS. has as yet been discovered. But another MS. containing a commentary named ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Éhas been discovered at Kudalur Mana, in Malabar in A.D.1919-20. A copy of it has been deposited in the Gov-

ernment Oriental MSS. Library, madras, thetext of Udbha·π≠a adopted by this commentator is the same as thatof IndurƒÅja and from its contents the commentary appearsto be written after IndurƒÅja. We can even assert that thecommentator came after Mamma·π≠a as he derives a greatdeal of matter directly from ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂. Out of about 50 extraquotations that the commentator has taken to elucidatehis points, about 20 are drawn from ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂,and manytimes he almost verbally borrows passages from that great work. In his treatment of ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞ hegives the illustration ‡§®‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã‡§Égiven by Mamma·π≠a in his ‡§ï‡§æ.‡§™‡•ç‡§∞.and putshis argument on it thus:‚Äî

‚Äú‡§®‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ä‡§¶‡§§‡§ø‡•§

‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§®‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§ï‡§Ç, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§æ, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§£‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§®‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§ï‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø..‡•§‚Äù

The whole of this passage so closely resembles thecorresponding passage in ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂(p. 760) and the few changes that are made appear to be so deliberate and mechanical that no one will deny that the passage is borrowed from‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂. Such adaptations exist throughoutthe whole of this commentary; many of them are pointedout or quoted in extracts in our Notes.

From this we can decide that the author of this ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§øcame after Mamma·π≠a, although how longafter, we have at present no means to decide. The writer mentions by name ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü, ‡§≠‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π, ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ü, and ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§® but not ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ü, We are inclined to think that he must have lived shortly after ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ü, This ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§ø is evidently a distinct workfrom ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§ï or ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞ of ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï mentioned by ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§∞‡§•. There is no mention of the author of the ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§øin the MS.

From the numerous references to previous interpretations of the KƒÅrikƒÅs of Udbha·π≠a, that exist in the ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§ø one is led to infer that several other commentaries must have existed before this ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞.In commenting upon ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç, the ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ refers

to five different views on the interpretation of this definitionof the figure ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏.His words are(1) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§∞‡•á;(2)…‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á; (3) ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§∞‡•á; (4)…‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§£‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•á; (5)…‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§É, (See our extract from the ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§ø in the notes on the definition of ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏ p.2, 1.7)None of these references point to anything contained inIndurƒÅja’s Laghuv·πõitti and we must conclude that therewere several other exegetes who had tried their hand onUdbha·π≠a’s famous work.

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§É‡•§

‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§õ‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ö‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§É‡••‡•ß‡••

‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ç‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡••‡•®‡••

‡§Ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ‡§ú‡•Å‡§∑‡§É
‡§∂‡•å‡§∞‡•á‡§É‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Ä‡§§‡§ó‡§≠‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§≠‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§ü‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§∞‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡§æ ‡§π‡•á‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ
‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡§∂‡§¨‡§≤‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≠‡§Æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡••‡•ß‡••

‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§≠‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§≠‡§Ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•å‡§∞‡§ø ‡§§‡§µ ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡••‡•®‡••

‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§ß‡§ø‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§É‡••‡•©‡••

‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§µ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§ö‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•á‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡•ã ‡§π‡§ø ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡•á‡§® ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡•ã‡§™‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡•à‡§µ‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‚Äì

‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡§Ç‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§π‡•à‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•å ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡§Æ‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç‚Äì ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç (‡§™‡§æ. ‡•´-‡•™-‡•ß‡•Æ) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É‡•§

‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§

‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§¶‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡•§ ‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É‡§™‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§≠‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•á‡§§‡•á ‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á ‡§™‡§¶‡•á ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§π‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§Ø‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§É‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§™‡§¶‡•ã ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§π‡§ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§ï‡§É ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§π‡§ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§¨‡•Ä‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á‡§™‡§¶‡•á ‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•á‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•á ‡§µ‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§π ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§É‡•§ ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•á ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§µ‡§Æ‡§®‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡•à‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Å ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•á ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ ‡§â‡§™‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§ ‡§á‡§π ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•á‡§Ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•á‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§ö ‡§™‡§¶‡•á ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§™‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§ ‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡§¶‡§∏‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§∞‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§£‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•Å ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡•á‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§∞‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§∞‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç‡•§

‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§É‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§ï‡•Å‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ó‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§§‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§≤‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§É‡••*‡•ß‡••

‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§§‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§É‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§É ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡§∂‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡§§‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•ã‡§ï‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•Ä‡§°‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏ ‡§§‡§•‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡•§

‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§ï‡•Å‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§∞‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•å ‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ó‡§≤‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•å ‡§ö ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ü‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•á‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡•§ ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§ï‡•Å‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§∞‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§ú‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ö‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§É ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§∞‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§É‡•§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ó‡§≤‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡•ã‡§™‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•å‡§®‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ó‡§≤‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ö‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§§‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‡§®‡§®‡•Å ‡§õ‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§™‡§†‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§•‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ø ‡§è‡§µ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§ ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§£‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§ß‡§ø‡§ó‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§π‡•à‡§µ‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§É‡•§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§∂‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§™‡§æ‡§†‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§†‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¨‡§≤‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§

‡§õ‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‡•§

‡§õ‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∏‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•å‡••‡•©‡••

‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡§≤‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•Å ‡§∏‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•á ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•á ‡§∏‡§§‡§ø‡§õ‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‚Äî‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•á ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‚Äî‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§£‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∏‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø ‡§ï‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡•§ ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø

‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§£‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ç‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§∏‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§ï‡•É‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§∏‡§§‡§ø ‡§õ‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡§æ ‡§® ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§ï‡•É‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§Ø‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§õ‡•á‡§ï‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äî ‡§õ‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∂‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•É‡§ó‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§É‚Äî ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡•á‡§®‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡•Å‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§∂‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§ï‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§õ‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§•‡§µ‡§æ ‡§õ‡•á‡§ï‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§≠‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§õ‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡§æ‡•§

‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‡§∏ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ã ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§∂‡•à‡§≤‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•á‡•§
‡§ó‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ó‡•ã‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§•‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡••*‡•®‡••

‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ã ‡§ó‡•Å‡§π‡§æ‡•§ ‡§ó‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∞‡•¶‚Äì (‡§™‡§æ. ‡•¨-‡•™-‡•ß‡•´‡•≠) ‡§á‡§§‡•Ä‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§®‡§ø ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•á ‡§ó‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§É‡•§ ‡§ó‡•ã‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§É‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•à‡§É‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§•‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§£‡•à‡§É‡•§ ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§

‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•å ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•å ‡§ó‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ó‡•ã‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•Ä‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§•‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•å ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø-‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•å ‡§ö ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•å ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•å ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡§≤‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡•å ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∏‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§æ‡§µ‡•Å‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•å ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§õ‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡§æ‡•§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§†‡§É‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ö‡•à‡§§‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§£‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡•§

‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‡•§ ‡§∏ ‡§ö ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•ã ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø-(‡§ï‡§æ.‡§∏‡§æ.‡§∏‡§Ç. ‡§™‡•É. ‡•¨ ‡§™‡§Ç. ‡•®‡•®)

‡§∏‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å‡•§
‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ï‡•ç ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ó‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∂‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§µ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡•§

‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É‡•§ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ï‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§µ‡§Ø‡§É

‡§∏‡§¶‡•á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§

‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡•§

‡§∂‡§∑‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∞‡•á‡§´‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§£ ‡§ö ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§π‡•ç‡§≤‡§π‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡••‡•™‡••

‡§∂‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§∞‡•á‡§´‡•ã‡§™‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§∞‡•á‡§´‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§É ‡§ü‡§†‡§°‡§¢‡§£‡•á‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§™‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‡•§

‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡•ã‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§ï‡•Å‡§∂‡•á‡§∂‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•á ‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡§™‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ ‡§∂‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡••*‡•©‡••

‡§§‡•ã‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∂‡•á‡§∂‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡•à‡§É ‡§ï‡§™‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§™‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§Ü‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ó‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§∂‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§£‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‡•§

‡§â‡§™‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡•§

‡§∏‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§â‡§™‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§É‡••‡•´‡••
