P. 56, L. 6‚Äî‡§á‡§π ‡§∞‡§∏‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç…..‡•§ The twofold character of ‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ω and ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ω when they are consistent or not with the convention of scriptures has been already explained. Out of them those that are consistent are spoken of as ‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ω and ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ω, and those that are inconsistent are termed ‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ω and ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ω. And when the abatement of the operation of these sentiments and feelings and their semblances with reference to the objects of their origin is described in poetry, it gives rise to the ala·πÖkƒÅra ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§; for there their abatement or complete resignation takes place. The word ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§ is derived by the termination ‡§§in the sense of the action of ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§®, as ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç.

** P. 56, L. 11**‚Äî‡§®‡§®‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø…..‡•§ Now if the operation of the sentiments and feelings is withheld in that poem, then in that case by the cessation of the old sentiments new sentiments etc. being introduced, they will give rise to such ala·πÖkƒÅras as ‡§∞‡§∏‡§µ‡§§‡•çand others. The author removes this doubt by the expression ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ etc. It mens the cessation should be completely void of the ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ωetc. of another sentiment. Thus where notwithstanding the deep impression of the former sentiments and feelings, they are completely set at rest, and new sentiments do not rise at

all, or when they do rise they are somehow subdued, there the ala·πÖkƒÅra ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§ makes its appearance.

The ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞’s comment on these lines is shortly as follows:‚Äî‡§Ö‡§®‡•å‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§∞‡§∏‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§É ‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∞‡§∏‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§¨‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§® ‡§ö ‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ã‡§Ω‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•á‡§£ ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§

** P. 57, L. 1**‚Äî‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å…‡•§ “‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§ is [the description of] a thing possessed of immense wealth or a deed of a great person, both of which are not the principal themes [of the poem]”.

The ‡§ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å or ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ must be only touched upon secondarily, they must not be dwelt upon to a great length.

‡§â‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö ‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§°‡•á etc., ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡•Ä‡§≤‡§µ‡•à‡§°‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø etc., ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ etc., ‡§¨‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§≤ etc.‚Äîall this is a description of the wealthy HimƒÅlaya. The idea in the last verse is worth noticing. At the time of the final chaos, the earth fell down to hell; but HimƒÅlaya did not fall with it; on the contrary the [immense] length of it became manifest, its bottom being severed from the earth.

The ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ reads ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡•Ä‡§≤ etc. and explains as ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§É.

** P. 57, L. 24**‚Äî‡§® ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§≤‡§∂‡§Ø‡§ö‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§§‡•á…..‡•§ If the deeds of a hero (‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§) is the principal theme of description then the sentiments occurring in the deeds of the hero willinvite the possibility of ‡§∞‡§∏‡§µ‡§¶‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ in that case. Therefore the condition is laid down as ‡§â‡§™‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•çetc.When the‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ is subordinately brought in, then that is the province of ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§. For ‡§∞‡§∏‡§µ‡§§‡•ç requires the sentiment to be working. prominently in the sentence, which is impossible when the source of the sentiment i. e.‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ is subordinate.

‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É‚Äî‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§ö‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§® ‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∞‡§∏‡§µ‡§¶‡§≤‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§â‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡•§ ‡§®‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

** P. 58, LL. 13‚Äì17**‚Äî‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§è‡§ï‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç………‡•§ “The composition (1) of words (of different meanings). which are pronounced in the same manner and (2) of words which appear to have the same pronunciation but

which really differ in some attributes such as ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç etc. is called ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü.”

** P. 58, L. 16.**‚Äî‡§Ö‡§≤‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç……‡•§ ‚ÄúThus composed of two kinds of words (‡§™‡§¶‡§Ω) [the figure‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü] which produces an image of other ala·πÖkƒÅras should be regarded as [two fold] distinguished by an expression of ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•and ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶."

** P. 58, L. 18 to P. 59, L. 5**‚Äî‡§á‡§π ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Å‚Ä¶.‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§The words having different meanings are regarded by Udbha·π≠a as different words though they are made up of exactly the same letters and are pronounced alike. Now some words are exactly alike each other in both meanings, and some words differ slightly by a ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§, ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§®, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§® etc. When the two forms are exactly alike, the word employed only once can convey both meanings. In this case the ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑ is ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑. But when the two forms of the word (or the two different words according to Udbha·π≠a’s doctrine) are not exactly alike but differ in some minor attributes such as ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ etc., one form is expressed and the other form comes in jointly with the first by similarity. In this case it is ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü for not only the meaning but the verbal form even has to come in jointly.

P. 59, LL. 6‚Äì9‚Äî‡§è‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ç…… ‡§™‡§¶‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É‡•§ IndurƒÅja explains the second KƒÅrikƒÅ. Here he argues in a grammatical style. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§übecomes an ala·πÖkƒÅra by creating an image of some other ala·πÖkƒÅra. Therefore wherever ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§üexists some other ala·πÖkƒÅra necessarily exists, and so ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ücannot have any independentexistence (‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂).But the other ala·πÖkƒÅras have their own independent provinces quite unconnected with ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü, while‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü cannot have the same.Therefore in cases whereBut the other ala·πÖkƒÅras have their own independent provinces quite unconnected with ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü, while‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü cannot have thesame.Therefore in cases where‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü occurs, the claims of othres ala·πÖkƒÅras are ignored and‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§üonly

is noticed.

According to grammar there is a rule ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡•á‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø. There is another axiom of a similar import viz, ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§™‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç. When a greater category completely overlaps a smaller one and extends further, there remains no province for the smaller category. Therefore it becomes an exception and wrests its own

province from the larger category. The larger category thus exists in the province outside the reach of the smaller one. Now, as ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü in all cases produces some other ala·πÖkƒÅra, wherever ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü exists some other ala·πÖkƒÅra invariably exists. These other ala·πÖkƒÅras have their own independent examples also. Thus if the claims of ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑ are ignored, ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑ is entirely lost, but if the claims of other ala·πÖkƒÅras are ignored they are not entirely lost. Therefore wherever‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü occurs other ala·πÖkƒÅras recede and give place to.

** P. 59, L. 12**‚Äî‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ Udbha·π≠a gives three verses to illustrate ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü. The examples ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü of ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü are interspersed in them and it requires a great grammatical labour to determime whether a particular word contains‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü or‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü according to the views of Udbha·π≠a. It will always require an extensive knowledge of Pa·πáini’s Grammar to determine whether two forms of a word differ by ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§, ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§ or ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ or by ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§® etc.

** P. 59. L. 13**‚ÄîVerse 1 ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞…..‡•§ Here the ala·πÖkƒÅra is ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü, i. e. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü is the principal figure and there is only a tinge of ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ is compared to PƒÅrvatƒ´by paronomastic adjectives. ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞ and ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™ are paronomastic (‡§∏‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü). ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞=(1) arms that are resplendent, (2) rays of the sun; ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™=(1) ‡§Ö ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§Ü‡§™=‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡§≠, difficult to be obtained; (2) remaining awake, not sleeping. The ‡§™‡§¶‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§¶ in the case of the first meaning of ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™ in ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§´‡§≤‡§≤‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ is ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§≤‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§É ‡§§‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§à‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•å; and in the case of the second meaning is ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§´‡§≤‡§≤‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§® ‡§≤‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§É ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡•á ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•å. Thus the compound is quite different in both the meanings. Hence a change of ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ω and ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§Ω takes place when the meaning is changed. But on account of similarity of both the forms, the one is expressed and the other is ‡§Ü‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§§, hence this is ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü.

In the case of ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞,the compound in the first meaning (‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§ï‡§∞‡•å) is ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø (i. e. a variety of ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑) and in the second meaning (‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§É) it is ‡§∑‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•Ä‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑. Therefore there is no change in ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ω etc. and the figure is ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑; for the form is the same and the meaning is only ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü (adhering to the principal meaning).

** P. 59, L. 15‚Äì16**‚ÄîVerse 2. ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•Ä….‡•§Here the ala·πÖkƒÅra according to Udbha·π≠a is ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü. There is ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ between PƒÅravatƒ´(understood) and ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ú‡§ó‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®. PƒÅrvatƒ´is termed ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ú‡§ó‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§® i. e. ‡§Ö‡§≤‡•å‡§ï‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®. All the attributes ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•Ä etc. qualifiy PƒÅrvatƒ´and ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ú‡§ó‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§® as well‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ú‡§ó‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®also has a double use; it qualifies PƒÅrvatƒ´once and at another time it becomes an independent word and produces an image of ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ïas said above.

Here ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ú‡§ó‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§® not differ in its two forms either by ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞ or ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®; for both the meanings of it are only side-lights of one and the same meaning. Therefore it is an example of ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑. In ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä the ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞ is changed and in ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•Ä and other adjectives the ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§® is changed. Hence they become examples of ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑.

Verse 3 (first half) ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ……..‡•§ Here the ala·πÖkƒÅra according to Udbha·π≠a is ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü is principal and ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß is subordinate. ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§É=(1) [one] whose beauty is delighting, (2) the splendour of the Nandana garden.‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ=(1) [one] in whose connection tidings of enemies are absent; (2) [garden] in which there is no trace of ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§§tree.

The first meaning of‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Äqualifies PƒÅrvatƒ´and the second being an independent one becomes ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® and produces ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ of ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï. The first meaning of ‡§Ö‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ qualifies PƒÅrvatƒ´and thesecond meaning qualifies the second meaning of ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä. Thus the ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï becomes: “PƒÅrvatƒ´is‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä (splendor of the garden ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®) itself having no ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§§ tree in it‚Äù. Now here ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß or ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏ is produced which is based on the ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï that is created by the word ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä. ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§§ tree is said to be not existing in Nandana which is absurd, for‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§§ is invariably associated with Nandana. The ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∞of this ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß is to be made by accepting the first meanings of both the words which qualify PƒÅrvatƒ´.

Here there is a change in the ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ω of both the words when the meaning changes. For the compounds become different when the meaning is changed. Hence both are ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ω and not ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ω,

Verse 3 (latter half). ‡§Ö‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•Ä…….‡•§Here the ala·πÖkƒÅra is ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü.

‡§Ö‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•Ä=(1) beautiful like the moon [reflected] in water; (2) a beautiful lady having no ‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å(spot), ‡§ó‡§≤‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ=[Lady] from whom are issuing drops of lustre.

Here the second meaning of‡§Ö‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•Ä is contradictory to the meaning of‡§ó‡§≤‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ. A lady having no ‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Åis said to be the source of‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å drops (of lustre); hence the ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß. The ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ßis removed by accepting the first meaning of ‡§Ö‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•Ä.

Although in ‡§Ö‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•Ä thecompound is different when meaning changes, the ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞does not change. But the ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§® does change when the compound is changed, and the two forms of the word become different in that respect. Therefore ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑ is present here.

The differences occurring in the ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ω of these three verses are not explained at length. It is always laborious and many times useless to explain the intricate technicalities of grammar about ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ω which are invariably found in Vedic literature. Those who are interested in these ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ω should study the commentary and those who want to enter deeper into the subject should see ‚ÄòMacdonell’s Vedic Grammar for students, Ap. III.’ The best way, however, will be to consult the ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ in‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡•å‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•Ä, especially the ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ω.

But to understand the text and especially the commentary on this portion, it is necessary and sufficient to explain here the modifications of ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ω in three cases viz. ‡§•‡§æ‡§•‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø, ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§π‡§ø and ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ω.

P. 60, L. 2‚Äî‡§•‡§æ‡§•‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§The s≈´tra which enjoins the ‡§•‡§æ‡§•‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞ is ‚Äò‡§•‡§æ‡§•‡§æ‡§ò‡§û‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§ú‡§¨‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äô(‡§™‡§æ. ‡•¨.‡•®.‡•ß‡•™‡•™.) which is explained in ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ as‚Äî‡§•, ‡§Ö‡§•, ‡§ò‡§û‡•ç, ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§, ‡§Ö‡§ö‡•ç, ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç, ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§ï ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ã‡§™‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø, and means ’the last syllable of words ending in suffixes ‡§•, ‡§Ö‡§• etc. becomes ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§when they are the latter members of com-

pounds with prepositions or substantives ending in cases forming the first members. The words ending in‚Äî

suffix ‡§• are ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•Ä‡§•‡§É, ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§≠‡•É‡§•‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•É‡§•‡§É;

suffix ‡§Ö‡§• are ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§∏‡§•‡§É, ‡§â‡§™‡§µ‡§∏‡§•‡§É;

suffix ‡§ò‡§û‡•ç are‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§É, ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§É, ‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•Å‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§É;

suffix ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§are ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Å‡§§‡§É;

suffix ‡§Ö‡§ö‡•çare‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§É, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§Ø‡§É;

suffix ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç are ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§µ‡§É, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§µ‡§É;

suffix ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ are‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç; and in

suffix ‡§ïare ‡§ó‡•ã‡§µ‡•É‡§∑‡§É, ‡§ñ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡•É‡§∑‡§É.

The last syllable of all these words becomes ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§. Our example is ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§´‡§≤‡§≤‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ which is a compound, the last member of which ends in suffix ‡§Ö‡§ö‡•ç, and is preceded by the preposition ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞ and the substantive ‡§à‡§π‡§ø‡§§ or ‡§π‡§ø‡§§ in the accusative case; therefore its last syllable becomes ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§.

** P. 6O, L. 4.**‚Äî‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•á ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§§‡§ø‡•§ The s≈´tra prescribing the ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞ in a ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑ compound is ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•á ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É (‡§™‡§æ. ‡•¨.‡•®.‡•®). It is explained in ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ very clearly thus:‚Äî‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•á ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•á ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø. In a ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑ compound the first member retains its original accent. Thus ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§´‡§≤‡§≤‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡•á being a ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑ compound its first member has the original accent and is therefore ‡§Ü‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§ i. e. its first syllable is ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§.

** P. GO, L. 23**‚Äî‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§π‡•å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç. (‡§™‡§æ. ‡•¨.‡•®.‡•ß.). In a ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§π‡§ø compound, the first member retains its original accent. It does not get all ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§ accents by the rule ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§Æ‡•ç. Thus ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ébeing a ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§π‡§ø compound retains the original accent in its first member and does not take all ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ω except the last one which becomes ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§ by the general rule ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç.

The nature of the ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§≠‡•á‡§¶ in two forms of a word is as follows. When the compounds in a composite word change, following the change in the meaning, then there is ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§≠‡•á‡§¶ between the two forms of the word. Thus we have in ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•Ä two different compounds in its two different meanings, (1) ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•Ä ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä and (2) ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É

‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Ç or ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•á ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ú‡§ó‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ Thus here though the compound is ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§π‡§ø in both still the nature of them is quite different. Therefore a ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§≠‡•á‡§¶ exists here though there is no ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶ in the accents (‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ω). But in ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ú‡§ó‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç we have the same compound ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç in both the meanings. When we apply the word to PƒÅrvatƒ´, ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§® means ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å, and when it becomes an independent word ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§® means a jewel.

Thus by means of difference in ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞ (accent) and ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§® (stress or effort) the same expression consisting of the same letters is pronounced differently in different situations and in this way becomes instrumental in bringing out the kind of ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑ or the figure ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü recognised by Udbha·π≠a and supported by IndurƒÅja.

All this dry labour about the differences of ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞ and ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§® becomes unbearable in the province of poetry. Therefore Mamma·π≠a tells us to ignore it in a ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‚Äì‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§® ‡§ó‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á etc.I ‡§ï‡§æ. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞. ‡•Ø.

The ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞explains the KƒÅrikƒÅs 50 and 51 in the same strain and almost in the same words as IndurƒÅja; but he takes the three examples together and simultaneously remarks on them thus:‚Äî

‡§® ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§É‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ó‡•å‡§∞‡•Ä‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡§≤‡§Ø‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§§‡•á, ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§≤‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡§ø, ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡•á‡§∂‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ, ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§É (‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ), ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•å ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ‡•å ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ó‡§§‡§æ ‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É, ‡§Ü‡§π‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä ‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É, ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§¨‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ø ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§É ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•Ä, ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§ó‡§≤‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§µ‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§Ω‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ö‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§ø‡§§‡§æ, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§´‡§≤‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§® ‡§≤‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§É ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ω‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡§ø, ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§≤‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§É, ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ, ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§É, ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡•á‡§§‡§µ‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ú‡§ó‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç, ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡§§‡§æ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡•à‡§ï‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§•‡§æ‡§•‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•§ ‡§™‡§¶‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡§¶‡•á ‚Äò‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•á ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á‚Äô‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•à‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§¶‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§•‡§æ‡§•‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á ‡§â‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•à‡§ï‡§™‡§¶‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§™‡§¶‡§™‡§æ‡§†‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§É‡•§ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§π‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§π‡§ø ‚Äò‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§π‡•å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‚Äô‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§π‡§ø ‚Äò‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§π‡•å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‚Äô‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‚Äò‡§®‡§û‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‚Äô‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞

‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§π‡•å ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‚Äò‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•á ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á‚Äô‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§û‡•ç‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ, ‡§§‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§É‡•§

He, however, takes objection to the definition of ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑ itself as given by Udbha·π≠a and prefers to take all these examples as instances of ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞ or more equitably those of ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ and others. He goes on to say:‚Äî‡§è‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø‚Äî

‡§§‡•á ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§™‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á
‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø ‡§®‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ã
‡§Ø‡•á ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§æ ‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§æ‡••

‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•á ‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§•‡§µ‡§æ ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§® ‡§ö ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§®, ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§

‡§Ö‡§•‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡§µ‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§ï‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•Ç‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡•Å‡§™‡§Æ‡•à‡§µ ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§

‡§® ‡§ö ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑ ‡§â‡§™‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§É‡•§ ‡§µ‡•à‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ω‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§ó‡•ã‡§ö‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ã‡§Ω‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§® ‡§ö ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§ó‡•ã‡§ö‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ó‡§§‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§® ‡§ö ‡§≠‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§Ω‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ω‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§®‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§è‡§ï‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§™‡•á ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§ó‡§§‡•à‡§µ‡•§ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ç ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡§∂‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∏‡§≠‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•Å

‡§Ü‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§Æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§ö‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á
‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡•á ‡§≤‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ö‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ó‡§æ‡§¢‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§É‡•§
‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•á ‡§™‡§§‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§ï‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•á
‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§≤‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ ‡§® ‡§π‡§ø ‡§® ‡§π‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡§≤‡•á ‡§ö‡•ã‡§≤‡§ï‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡•§

(See ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ under ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑, p. 103)

‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∞‡•ã‡§π‡§É‡•§ ‡§® ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§á‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§á‡§µ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡§É‡•§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ü‡•á‡§®‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç (‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ü‡§É‚Äì‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É, ‡•™.‡•©‡•®.)‚Äî

‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å‡§ü‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡•Å‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡•å ‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡•§
‡§Ü‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§É‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡•§

‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö (‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ü‡§É‚Äî‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É, ‡•™.‡•©‡•©-‡•©‡•™.)‚Äî

‡§Ø‡§¶‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡•Ä‡§®‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡§∞‡§∏‡§É‡•§
‡§®‡§®‡•Å ‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ç ‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§∏‡•å ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§É‡••
[‡§µ]‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§®‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•§
‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§µ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡§É ‡§§‡§µ ‡§ö ‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ò‡§ü‡§§‡•á‡••

‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•á‡§π ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§® ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡•á‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡•à‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§•‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å‡•§ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§â‡§≠‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§® ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ù‡§ü‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

A great deal could be said about the views and ideas acceptable to Udbha·π≠a concerning the ala·πÖkƒÅra ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü. Udbha·π≠a has quite an independent treatment of it. But already Mr. K. P. Trivedi in his edition of EkƒÅvali has detailed the view of Udbha·π≠a in his notes and has compared it with Mamma·π≠a’s view. (Vide “The EkƒÅvali"B. S. S. No. 63; pp. 622‚Äì628). To describe the position of Udbha·π≠a with regard to the ala·πÖkƒÅra ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§üa brief statement will suffice here.

The difference between Udbha·π≠a and the writers older than Udbha·π≠a such as BhƒÅmaha, Da·πá·∏çin and others is as follows:‚Äî

[TABLE]

On the whole the ideas of the older writers seem to be more general and inexact. BhƒÅmaha, in particular, has treated the figure very scantily.

The difference between Udbha·π≠a and the modern writers of the Mamma·π≠a school is as under:

[TABLE]

[TABLE]

Mamma·π≠a has two sub-varieties of ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑ viz. ‡§∏‡§≠‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑and ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑. These generally correspond with the ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑ and ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑ of Udbha·π≠a. If the component parts of an epithet become different when the meaning is changed the ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑ is ‡§∏‡§≠‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó, e. g. ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§´‡§≤‡§≤‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ. Here the component words in one case (1) ‡§Ö + ‡§∏‡•Å + ‡§Ü‡§™ + ‡§´‡§≤ + ‡§≤‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß + ‡§à‡§π‡§ø‡§§ + ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ and in the other (2) ‡§Ö + ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™ + ‡§´‡§≤ + ‡§≤‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡•á, ‡§π‡§ø‡§§ + ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ are different, therefore it is ‡§∏‡§≠‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑. In such a case generally the ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§® etc. become different when the component words are changed; and thus it becomes Udbha·π≠a’s Similarly ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑ of Mamma·π≠a becomes generally the ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑ of Udbha·π≠a.

But this is a general statement. Sometimes ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑ of Udbha·π≠a may not have a change in its component parts.

Hence Ruyyaka remarks **‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡§É ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§£‡§™‡§¶‡§≠‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø.**Generally ‡§™‡§¶‡§≠‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó occurs where there is ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§≠‡•á‡§¶ etc.

In all this peculiar treatment of the ala·πÖkƒÅra, ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑, Ruyyaka of‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µa companion of Udbha·π≠a. BhƒÅmaha seems to have not even dreamt of such varieties as Udbha·π≠a has found in ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü. Mamma·π≠a distinctly refutes the principle of ‡§è‡§ï‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æin the division of ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§üby laying down the dictum that ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§® etc. are not be taken into account in poetry.

The principle of ‡§è‡§ï‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æmust really be a stumbling block to those students of ala·πÖkƒÅra who have no knowledge or only a scanty knowledge of Pa·πáini’s system of grammar. In former times the case was different. All students who were initiated into Vedic or S’ƒÅstric lore first used to acquire a considerable knowledge of PƒÅ·πáini’s system which always stood them in good stead in whatever further branch of learning they wanted to pursue. The study of ala·πÖkƒÅra was still more akin to VyƒÅkara·πáa as Al·πÖkƒÅra≈õƒÅstra was primarily based on VyƒÅkara·πáa. All the authors and learners too in that science were chiefly grammarians and any subject concerning the technicalities of grammar was freely introduced in their discussions.

  •    *

VARGA V.

** P. 62, LL. 2-4‚Äî**(KƒÅrikƒÅs 52, 53). The order of enumeration followed here is that of BhƒÅmaha. BhƒÅmaha has-

‡§Ö‡§™‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡•á‡••
‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø‡•§
‡§∏‡§π‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§Æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡••
** ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‚Äî‡•©. ‡•®‚Äî‡•©.**

Udbha·π≠a has no ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï and BhƒÅmaha fails to recognise ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞;otherwise the ala·πÖkƒÅras and their order of enumera-

tion are the same in both. But if we consult Da·πá·∏çin’s KƒÅvyƒÅdar≈õa we shall find that his order differs materially from the order of these two Kashmirians. We give below the lists of ala·πÖkƒÅras in order from the works of these three authors.
BhƒÅmaha. Udbha·π≠a Da·πá·∏çin ( KƒÅvyƒÅdar≈õa,ii, 6-7.)
‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§ ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§ ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§
‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§Ö‡§™‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡§ø
‡§Ö‡§™‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§™‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü
‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø
‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§æ
‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß
‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ
‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§ø
‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ
‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï …….. ………
‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ ………
‡§∏‡§π‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§π‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§π‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø
………. ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø
‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ü‡§∂‡•Ä‡§É
………. ………. ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ (‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞)

These lists clearly indicate that Da·πá·∏çin followed a tradition which was distinct from the Kashmirian tradition upheld by BhƒÅmaha and Udbha·π≠a.

However if we compare the whole lists of ala·πÖkƒÅras of these three authors we find that Da·πá·∏çin’s list agrees very closely with the list of BhƒÅmaha and Udbha·π≠a, so much so that we can almost say that the order followed in the treatment of ala·πÖkƒÅras is the same in the works of the three authors.

It is also curious to see that no other writer in ala·πÖkƒÅra literature substantially follows this order. VƒÅmana has his own distinct order. Rudra·π≠a arranges ala·πÖkƒÅras

according to an intrinsically different principle of classification; his treatment has very little in common with other writers. Mamma·π≠a arranges his 61 ala·πÖkƒÅras on a somewhat scientific basis and most writers after him more or less follow his grouping.

As between BhƒÅmaha, Udbha·π≠a and Da·πá·∏çin, we have pointed out that Da·πá·∏çin’s order of enumeration differs in a few important points from that of the other two. Da·πá·∏çin places ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§øat the very beginning of his list. His list has in order ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø, ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ, ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï, ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§ï, and ‡§Ü‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø; while the Kashmirians have ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï, ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§ï and ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ at the beginning of their treatment. They have no ‡§Ü‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø, and ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø stands thirteenth in their order. Da·πá·∏çin puts in ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å, ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æand ‡§≤‡§µ after ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ; while the Kashmirians do not recognise these three ala·πÖkƒÅras at all. Some further difference in the order occurs after ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§which we have specially referred to in the beginning of this discussion. (Vide the lists quoted above).

P. 62, L. 6‚Äì7‚Äî‡§Ö‡§™‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ ‡§ö‡•§ (KƒÅrikƒÅ 54). “That cherished figure is ‡§Ö‡§™‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡§øwhich includes ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ(similarity) in a slight degree. Wise men compose it by concealing the object belonging to the theme. (‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•=‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞-‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•=‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø).‚Äù

Udbha·π≠a’s definition of ‡§Ö‡§™‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡§øis practically the same as that of BhƒÅmaha. BhƒÅmaha has ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç instead of ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§µ‡•á‡§®. (‡§≠‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‚Äî‡•©.‡•®‡•¶.) But Da·πá·∏çin has quite & vague description of ‡§Ö‡§™‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡§ø, viz. ‡§Ö‡§™‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§™‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‚Äî‡•®. ‡•©‡•¶‡•™.

He does not seem to hold that ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ is necessary to form; **‡§Ö‡§™‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡§ø;**hence the denial of ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Øfor the sake of establishing its own excellence is not at all wanted by him and his examples also point to the same fact. His example is-

‡§® ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§∑‡•Å‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡••
‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂ ‚Äî‡•®. ‡•©‡•¶‡•™.

The real ‡§Ö‡§™‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡§ø as recognised by all other writers is e. g. ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï by him.

‡§®‡•à‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§®‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•å‡•§
‡§è‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á‡§∏‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§®‡•à‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡••
‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡••
‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§É‚Äî‡•®. ‡•Ø‡•™-‡•Ø‡•´.

VƒÅmana’s definition is‚Äî ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§≤‡§æ‡§™‡•ã‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‚Äî‡•™.‡•©.‡•´.
Here though he does not clearly state whether the ‡§Ö‡§™‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§µ is to be made of ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø or ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®, yet his example shows that he means the ‡§Ö‡§™‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§µ of ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø and of nothing else. All other writers such as Mamma·π≠

a, Ruyyaka, Rudra·π≠

a and those who came after them follow the definition of BhƒÅmaha and Udbha·π≠

a, which has (1) ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ and (2) the suppression of ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø as its two integral elements; and Da·πá·∏çin seems to be all alone with his ideas about ‡§Ö‡§™‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡§ø.

**P. 62, LL. 9, 10‚Äî**The MS. presents two blanks here. It is evident that some such words as those that are put into brackets must be originally existing there.

P. 62, LL. 21, 22‚Äî‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§™‡§ø ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç (KƒÅrikƒÅ 56)‡•§“Setting forth the non-production of effect even when the powers (causes) are all present, with a view to establish some peculiarity, is called ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø.”

P. 63, LL. 6, 7‚Äî‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§®(KƒÅrikƒÅ 56)‡•§ The varieties of ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§øare here described. “In poetry the beautiful structure of it (‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø) is observed to have two varieties, the one with the reason why the effect was not produced expressed, and the other with the reason not expressed.” We have taken ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø (the object) where the ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ (of ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø) is seen to be fulfilled i. e. a poem, and have translated it accordingly. Another interpretation is also possible, viz. ’the thing to be impressed,’ i. e. the ‡§´‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø; then the construction will be ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á (‡§´‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•å) ‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡•á‡§® etc.

The second variety viz. by ‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡•á‡§® is illustrated first.

P. 63, LL. 10, 11‚Äî‡§Æ‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§ø ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•á ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ …… ‡•§ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ = ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™, ‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡•ç‡§Øhere. Here‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ, ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Çand ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Éare the causes which are generallyseen to produce ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø. But the ‡§´‡§≤-‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø is here said to be not forthcoming. The ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑ that is sought to be conveyed

here is the wonder that springs from the ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Ås having failed to produce ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ. Here the reason (‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§) why ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ was not produced is not given, therefore this is ‡§Ö‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø.

P. 63, LI. 19. 23‚Äî ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•Å‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ……‡•§A hasty man always does his work very hastily. But here even a hasty man is described as not doing the action of asking in a hasty manner. ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ is the cause; ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§µ‡§ö‡§É ‡§®‡•ã‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡§ø is the denial of effect. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•Å‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ is the reason why his speech does not come out. Though the cause viz. ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ exists, yet the effect does not take place; hence a sort of wonder is produced which is the ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑sought to be conveyed. Or better, the ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑may be taken to be the extremeness of ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•Å‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§µ. PƒÅrvatƒ´’s action was so strange (‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•Å‡§≤) that even the impatient Sa·πÖkara was stunned to silence. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•Å‡§≤=cross, perverse, whimsical, strange.

Much need not be said about Udbha·π≠a’s ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø. His definition of the figure appears to be the undeveloped form of the definition of Mamma·π≠a which runs thus: ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á‡§∑‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§´‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§ö‡§É‡•§ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‚Äî‡•ß‡•¶, ‡§™‡•É. ‡•¨‡•´‡•Æ. Here ‡§Ö‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡•á‡§∑‡•Å is a paraphrase of Udbha·π≠a’s ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç and ‡§´‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§ö‡§É is the same as ‡§´‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç. We have always pointed out with emphasis the fact that although Mamma·π≠a’s wording does not always agree with that of Udbha·π≠a, his ideas and his treatment of ala·πÖkƒÅras in most cases bear a close resemblance with the contents of Udbha·π≠a’s work. His definitions of ala·πÖkƒÅras always borrow their ideas from Udbha·π≠a. Udbha·π≠a on his own part is indebted to BhƒÅmaha in much the same way as Mamma·π≠a is indebted to the former. But while admitting the general indebtedness of Udbha·π≠a to BhƒÅmaha we must not omit to notice the great stride of advance effected by Udbha·π≠a over the comparatively primitive structure of BhƒÅmaha. BhƒÅmaha’s ideas are, in many places, crude, vague and unsuited to the advanced notions that were in vogue in the time of Udbha·π≠a; therefore Udbha·π≠a polishes or improves upon them. Sometimes he puts his own wording in the place of that of BhƒÅmaha. The figure ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø is an instance in point. BhƒÅmaha’s definition and example are‚Äî

‡§è‡§ï‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡§Æ‡•á ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§É (or ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§É)‡•§
‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡••
‡§∏ ‡§è‡§ï‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§£‡§ø ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ß‡§É‡•§
‡§π‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§®‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§®‡§æ ‡§® ‡§π‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡••
‡§≠‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‚Äî‡•©. ‡•®‡•®-‡•®‡•©.

“When along with the withdrawal of one quality the existence of another quality is sought to be established for the purpose of conveying excellence, the figure is ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø"‚Äî according to BhƒÅmaha. It will be seen that this definition is of a different type from that of Udbha·π≠a and others. BhƒÅmaha does not require (1) the presence of ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ and (2) the non-occurrence of ‡§´‡§≤or ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Øas the important elements of the figure. It is true that his illustration is an excellent example of ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§øeven from the modern point of view and is quoted by Mamma·π≠a as ‡§Ö‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø. But the view-point of BhƒÅmaha and the modern ƒÄla·πÖkƒÅrikas is different. BhƒÅmaha seems to regard ‡§§‡§®‡•Åand ‡§¨‡§≤ as two qualities of ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ß (‡§Æ‡§¶‡§®) of which the former is suppressed and the latter extolled; while the modern ƒÄla·πÖkƒÅrikas would regard ‡§¨‡§≤‡§π‡§∞‡§£(which is here denied, as the result (‡§´‡§≤) of the cause (‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£) ‡§§‡§®‡•Å‡§π‡§∞‡§£. It will thus be clear how Udbha·π≠a has abandoned BhƒÅmaha and has created a new definition of ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§øwhich has proved acceptable to all who came after him.

P. 63, LL. 25, 26‚Äî‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§É ‡•§ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§æ……(KƒÅrikƒÅ 57)‡•§ “The expression of a thing different and contradictory to the quality or action [of the ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å] for the purpose of establishing the excellence [of it] is called ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß.”

Here ‘‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ’ seems incomplete. Hence IndurƒÅja supplies ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø, by the reptition of the word ‡§µ‡§æ-‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø. The ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ supplies ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§ø and ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‚Äî‡§µ‡§æ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•á . But the word ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ö‡§É seems to have proved a hard nut for the commentators to crack. IndurƒÅja’s explanation amounts to this‚Äî‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ (i. e. ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡§Ç, ‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É, ‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡§µ‡§É ‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É) ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ö‡§É, i. e. ‘imaginary creation by the poet of a thing contradictory (to the ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å) etc.’ The ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ has ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§Ø(‡§ü)‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç, which is rather

unintelligible. It amounts to what IndurƒÅja has given as his explanation. It seems better to take ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æin the ordinary sense viz. ‘action’. This word ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æshould include under it ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£ and ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø by ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ. The expanded definition will then become‚Äî‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ (‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§æ) ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß-‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø-(‡§ó‡•Å‡§£-‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø)-‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ-‡§µ‡§ö‡§É ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§É etc, which is quite correct, intelligible and suitable to the example given.

P. 64, L.10‚Äî‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É …‡•§ In this example the two opposite ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£s viz. ‡§ï‡•ã‡§Æ‡§≤‡§§‡§æ and ‡§§‡§™‡§É ‡§™‡§æ‡§ü‡§µ reside in the same person (‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä) at the same time.

Bhamaha’s definition of ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ßis‚Äî

‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ö‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§É‡••
‡§≠‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‚Äî‡•©.‡•®‡•™.

Rudra·π≠a’s definition very clearly confirms the interpretation of ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ö‡§É (KƒÅrikƒÅ 57) that we have offered above. He has :-

‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§•‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§è‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§É‡••
‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‚Äî‡•Ø.‡•©‡•¶.

‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç=‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç. In the above example the two opposite ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£s viz. ‡§ï‡•ã‡§Æ‡§≤‡§§‡§æ and ‡§§‡§™‡§É‡§™‡§æ‡§ü‡§µ reside in the same thing (‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä) at the same time.

All these writers, of course, have no idea about the real nature of ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß such as is defined by Mamma·π≠a, viz. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§É ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§É. They are not at all aware of the notion that the ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß(contradiction) between things should not be real but an apparent one. Real contradiction according to Mamma·π≠a is a fault in poetry. Hence it should not exist at all. Thus all the examples of the authors like BhƒÅmaha, Udbha·π≠a and others do not fall under Mamma·π≠a’s ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß. The present example of Udbha·π≠a‚Äî‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§§‡§™‡§∏‡§ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§ü‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç is an example of ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ (first variety) according to Mamma·π≠a, ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡•à‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡•ã ‡§ò‡§ü‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‚Äî‡§ï‡§æ. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞. ‡•ß‡•¶. p. 719.

VƒÅmana in his ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ gives the definition of ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß according to Mamma·π≠a’s standpoint. He has ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç

‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§É. But the examples given by VƒÅmana fall under the ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ of Mamma·π≠

a and later writers.

The underlying reason of this vagueness‚Äîand inaccuracy from the modern point of view‚Äîin the ideas of the older writers such as BhƒÅmaha, Udbha·π≠

a, VƒÅmana and others is in the fact that they failed to discriminate between different types of contradiction or antagonism of sense to be found in poetry. Later writers from the age of Mamma·π≠

a mention alankƒÅras such as ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß, ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡§§‡§ø, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Æ, and ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ïeach of which contains a distinct type of contradiction. All the ala·πÖ

kƒÅras, viz. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß, ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡§§‡§ø, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Æ and ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï of modern authors contain some kind of contradiction and the old authors, not being very minute in their descrimination, called all these different types of contradiction by one and the same name ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß. Hence their definitions are rather vague and their examples also do not stand the modern test of criticism and sometimes do not even satisfy the conditions laid down by their own definitions.

P. 64, LL. 20-21‚Äî‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§ ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø….‡•§(KƒÅrikƒÅ 58.) The prose order of words is :‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§É ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ [‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•à‡§É] ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø [‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç] ‡§µ‡§ö‡§É [‡§∏‡§æ] ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§ ‚Äú The expression conveying similarity between things that are both ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§or between things that are both **‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§,**the things themselves not being intended either as ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® or ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø, is ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§æ.‚Äù

The things between which similarity is expressed must all be either ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§or ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§; naturally, therefore, there cannot be any ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ between them. For ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® is a thing which is always ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§, while ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Øis that which is always ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§.

P. 64, L. 25‚Äî‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶ is that which is indicated by ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§É in the KƒÅrikƒÅ. ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Å‡§É etc.I Here ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§§‡•Ä, ‡§∂‡§∂‡§≠‡•É‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§ñ‡§æ and ‡§ï‡§¶‡§≤‡•Ä are all ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§, ‡§ï‡§†‡•ã‡§∞‡§§‡§æ is the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æbetween them. Though Udbha·π≠

a, like Mamma·π≠

a, does not say in his definition that ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ is necessary for the formation of ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§æ, yet he states it in his examples; for really there is no other way of conveying similarity between things which are all either ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§or ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§.

P. 65, LL 6-8‚Äî‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§É ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§™‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡•ã ‡§ú‡§ü‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç ….‡•§Here similarity between ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§™‡§ü‡•ç‡§†, ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç and ‡§Æ‡•É‡§ó‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§® is shown by the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•å‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø (unfittedness for the delicate frame of PƒÅrvati).

In ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§æUdbha·π≠a has approached very near towards Mamma·π≠a and has left BhƒÅmaha and Da·πá·∏çin far in the distance. Mamma·π≠a has ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ï‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§æ(‡§ï‡§æ. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞. ‡•ß‡•¶ p. 642) as his definition of ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§æ. Udbha·π≠a does not expressly say that one and only one ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æof the things that are similar must be stated, for ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø in ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø‡§øcannot be taken to mean ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ. It can only mean similarity or commonness and not ‘common quality.’ Yet it will be seen that in ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§æthere is no other way of expressing similarity except by the statement of ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ. There is no ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ, no ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ï‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶, nothing of the kind. The statement of **‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ,**therefore, comes as a matter of course though not included in Udbha·π≠a’s definition. Butthe rule, established by Mamma·π≠a, that only one ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æshould be stated is absent in Udbha·π≠a.

BhƒÅmaha’s ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§æ is :‚Äî

‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á‡§® ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡••
‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‚Äî‡•©.‡•®‡•¨.

Da·πá·∏çin has :‚Äî

‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡••
‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‚Äî‡•®.‡•©‡•©‡•¶.

Both the definitions are very similar though differently worded. There is no restriction that both the parts must be either ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§ or ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§. On the other hand it seems clear that one part of the comparison is to be ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§and the other to be ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§. The ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§æ of these writers, therefore, does not very much differ from ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§ï. Modern authors like Mamma·π≠a would certainly include it under ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§ï. In ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§ïone of the parties between which similarity is sought to be expressed is ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§ and the other is ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§. The ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§ thing is the ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø and the ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§ is the ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®. In ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§æ both or all the parties are either ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§ or ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§ and there

is no ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ existing between them. This is the point of difference between ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§ï and ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§æ, otherwise they are all similar. Udbha·π≠

a and following him Mamma·π≠

a have discerned this point of difference while BhƒÅmaha and Da·πá·∏ç

in have failed to do so. Udbha·π≠

a’s definition of ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§ï is‚Äî

‡§Ü‡§¶‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡•• (KƒÅrikƒÅ 14)

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡§É=‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§É Mamma·π≠

a also clearly brings out this difference. His ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§ï is ‡§∏‡§ï‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç and his ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§æ is ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ï‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§æ. ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç is explained as ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§µ‡§æ.

** P. 65, LL. 12-15**‚Äî‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡•á‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø… (KƒÅrikƒÅ 59)‡•§ ‚ÄúThe commendatory statement of an object removed from the principal theme of description but conveying with it a sense of the principal theme (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§), is called ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ.”

P. 65, LL.. 16-17‚Äî‡§® ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø … ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§ If the ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§ is driven away and the ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§is elaborately described in its place, then it will only have the value of the ravings of a madman who does not even understand what he has to describe. But such is not the case in ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ.‡§Ø‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ… ‡§®‡•Å‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡•§‚ÄîFor in ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ the ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§ which is stated brings with it by suggestion the principal theme of description (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§).

P. 65, L. 17‚Äî‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® = ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§®. Some kind of relation exists between the ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§ and the ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§; and it is owing to this relation (‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß) the ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§• comes in by implication. The ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß is either ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß, ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß or ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß.

** P. 65, LL. 20-21**‚Äî‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ú‡§∞‡§æ…..‡•§“The rustic charms of inaccessible regions consisting of an abundance of fruits and flowers wither in their places not having found any enjoyer.” All this is ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§and conveys the‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§sense that PƒÅrvati’s beauty will die away not having found any enjoyer in this condition of ascetic life.

BhƒÅmaha has as his definition of ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‚Äî

‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡•á‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§®‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡••
‡§≠‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‚Äî‡•®. ‡•®‡•Æ.

Udbha·π≠a has improved this happily by putting ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä. BhƒÅmaha has not that word in his definition but he means it; otherwise his definition would only apply to the ravings of a madman as IndurƒÅja says above. Neither BhƒÅmaha nor Udbha·π≠a try to distinguish the different varieties of **‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ.**Ruyyaka in his ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ writes down distinct varieties: (‡•ß) ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á, (‡•®) **‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á,**and (‡•©) ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á i. e. ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á. Mamma·π≠a has a similar but still more elaborate and minute treatment of ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ. (Vide ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂ ‡•ß‡•¶. pp. 618-627).

The modern commentator ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞brings in his commentary these divisions of ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ærecognised by modern authors. He says :-
(‡•ß) ‡§è‡§∑‡§æ ‡§ö (i. e. ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•á‡§∑‡•Å etc.) ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡•§
(‡•®) ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§£‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§É‡§∂‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§∑‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø
‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç, ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ-

‘‡§∏‡•Å‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§¨‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§ú‡§≤‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§Ø‡§É‡•§
‡§∏ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§™‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏ ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É‡••‚Äô

(‡•©) ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§∏ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ, ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‚Äî

‘‡§ê‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§∂‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•É‡§∂‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ß‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•§
‡§Æ‡•á‡§∞‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø ‡§® ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§∞‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡••’

** (‡•™) ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ï‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É, ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‚Äî**

‘‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä’‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡•§

(‡•´) ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•à‡§É ‡§ï‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡§π ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§∞‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø
‡§ó‡§§‡§æ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§Ç, ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‚Äî

“‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§æ ‡§® ‡§™‡§æ‡§†‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø’‡§§‡§ø‡•§

** **All this is after the manner of Mamma·π≠a and Ruyyaka. Mamma·π≠a lays down five varieties of ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§É‚Äî(‡•ß) ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ö‡§É, (‡•®) ‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ö‡§É,(‡•©) ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ö‡§É, (‡•™) ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ö‡§É and **(‡•´) ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ö‡§É.**Thus it will be seen that the passage above quoted from ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞exactly follows Mamma·π≠a.

Da·πá·∏çin has a very different sort of ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ, viz. the praise of any ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§thing with a view to condemn the ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§. BhojarƒÅja who belongs to the same school of ƒÄla·πÖkƒÅrikas as Da·πá·∏çin has also the same sort of ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ.

But the generality of ala·πÖkƒÅra writers does not seem to have accepted Da·πá·∏çin’s ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ; and Da·πá·∏çin with his follower Bhoja seems to be all alone with his rather queer ideas about this ala·πÖkƒÅra.

P. 66, LL.1-3‚Äî‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§®…‡•§‚Äî“Where censure is meant by the [direct] potentiality of words, but where praise is really desired to be principally understood, the figure is ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§ø.“‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É =‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡•å‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç = the tendency to express the meaning ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É = ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç=the natural disposition (of the ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø) to indicate a settled meaning. ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µis the natural tendency of a word to express a settled meaning i. e. the ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æprocess of a word.

P.66, L.6‚Äî‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ; ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•§See the words occurring in the commentary and noteson ‡§Ü‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§™, P. 48.

P. 66, LL. 13-15‚Äî‡§ß‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ã‡§™‡§π‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ **‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ=**itself, i. e. the ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶itself. The condemnation meant by the word ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡•çdoes not end in itself. Though the word ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡•çmeans condemnation outwardly its true aim is different. It really suggests the unrivalled beauty of PƒÅrvati.

P. 66, LL. 11-12‚Äî ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ó‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã…‡•§ This is not a very good example of ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§ø, for the censure of PƒÅrvati’s ‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø can be taken to be a real one. PƒÅrvatƒ´’s ‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø is really censurable if it hinders her union with a fit husband. For the sole aim of ‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡•ç‡§Øis to obtain a fit companion for one’s life. This kind of meaning indicating the reality of ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ælingers in our mind when we read the verse. Such a thing is not at all desirable in ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§ø.The examples‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø etc. and ‡§π‡•á ‡§π‡•á‡§≤‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§µ etc. given by Mamma·π≠a (vide ‡§ï‡§æ.‡§™‡•ç‡§∞.‡•ß‡•¶.pp. 670-71) are very appropriate and beautiful. In them the outward
‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æand ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§øare absolutely unreal. Mamma·π≠a’s definition of ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§øis‚Äî

‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§¢‡§ø‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡•§
** ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂ - ‡•ß‡•¶,** p. 670.

It means:‚Äî “censure or praise at first sight, the final apprehension (‡§∞‡•Ç‡§¢‡§ø‡§É) being the reverse of it, is called ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§ø.” Thus it will be seen that Mamma·π≠a, and fol-

lowing him other modern authors, recognise ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§øas twofold: (1) where ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æis apparent and ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§øis real, and (2) where ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§øis apparent and ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æis real. Udbha·π≠a recognises only the first variety of these two and frames his definition and example accordingly. Mamma·π≠a gives a twofold derivation of the word ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§øto suit his two varieties ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§É Udbha·π≠a seems to admit only ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§ø.

** P. 66, LL. 20-21‚Äî‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§É**…‡•§ (KƒÅrikƒÅ 61). “When an impossible relation between two things or a possible one causes comparison(‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ) between the two things to be understood, then the figure is called ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ.”

P. 66, LL. 22-24‚Äî‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç… ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ‡•§(1) When the expressed relation between two things being impossible suggests ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µbetween these two things then the figure is ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ. (2) Also when the possible connection between two things brings in ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µas a support to itself the figure is ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ.

P. 66, L. 24‚Äî‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã… ‡§™‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§ IndurƒÅja explains the word ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æaccording to its etymology. Now the word ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æas the name of this ala·πÖkƒÅrais very peculiar and uncommon. All writers on ala·πÖkƒÅraexcept Udbha·π≠a have uniformly used the word ‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æand nobody even hints there is a variant ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æin use somewhere. Our original MS. invariably writes ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ, and IndurƒÅja also derives the word with the ‡§â‡§™‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó ‡§µ‡§øand not with ‡§®‡§øby the expression ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§Øetc. This circumstance precludes any possibility of a mistake at the hands of the scribe and we can feel certain that Udbha·π≠a’s text as received by IndurƒÅja contained the title ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ and not ‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ. But the Madras MS. containing the commentary ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§øhas the name‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ everywhere. This certainly raises some difficulty, but it cannot deter us from adopting‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ as the true title originally intended by Udbha·π≠a. IndurƒÅja is a very old commentator and he must have had a reliable text in his possession to comment upon. His declared authority is on the side of the name **‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ.**While the

Madras MS. is not always trustworthy and the commentator is silent on the point.

BhƒÅmaha’s definition of ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ or ‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ is:

‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§
‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§Ø‡§•‡•á‡§µ‡§µ‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡••
‡§≠‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞, ‚Äì ‡•©, ‡•©‡•®.

** **The definition is not quite clear in meaning, Still it is obvious that its sense is different from that of the definition of Udbha·π≠

a. Thus Udbha·π≠

a has here abandoned BhƒÅmaha and has created a new definition of his own, which was adopted by Mamma·π≠

a in later times. ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ï‡§É‡•§‚Äî ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂; ‡•ß‡•¶. p. 613.

P. 66, LL. 26-27‚Äî ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ã‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö……‡•§ Here the ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§§‡§æ (pallidity) of ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ä (night) is said to be borne by ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä which is impossible. For the ‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§æ of night is inherently different from the ‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§æof a lady. Thus the connection of ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ä and ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä expressed through ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§§‡§æ is impossible. A lady cannot hear the ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§§‡§æ of night. This impossibility brings in the comparison : ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¨‡§ø‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§â‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¨‡§ø‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡•§

** **This is the first variety illustrated. Example of the second variety is not given by Udbha·π≠

a. IndurƒÅja therefore brings in a verse of BhƒÅmaha to illustrate it.

The ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞’s comment runs thus : ‚Äî‡§®‡§®‡•Å ‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•à‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡•á ‡§Ö‡§≠‡•á‡§¶ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§§‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£ ‡§è‡§ï‡•ã ‡§® ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§≠‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•à‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§Ω‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‚Äî ‘‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§’ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡•á‡§™‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡•à‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡§ø‡§π ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§

** P. 67, LL. 10-11‚Äî‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç** etc.‡•§ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞, ‡•©. ‡•©‡•©. BhƒÅmaha has no varieties of ‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ like Udbha·π≠

a. He gives this single verse as the example of ‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ.

IndurƒÅja enters into a rather stiff discussion on this verse. As usual he has brought in the science of grammar to dilate upon. His discussion has two parts : (1) ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§Ø… ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ; here the discussion is grammatical and (2) ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø… ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§É; this explains how the

ala·πÖkƒÅra‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ is formed in the example ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§É etc. We take the second first.

P. 67, LL. 19-23 ‚Äî‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø… ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§É ‡•§ Here IndnrƒÅja makes the ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§∏‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Øi. e. shows how the example fits in with the definition of the ala·πÖkƒÅra. In this example the connection between ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É and ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç is possible and real, not impossible as in the first variety. For the rich people are really made to understand by the sun that prosperity is followed by adversity.
