This relation between ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É and ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç is called ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§ï‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É is the ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø(that which is directed or caused) and ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•çis the ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§ï(subject of the causal action). Now to establish the cogency of this ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§ï‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß comparison comes in. The sun (‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç) causes the rich people to understand that rise terminates in a fall just as his own rise terminates in setting. Thus the sun teaches the thing which is similar to, and is easily deduced from, his own conduct, viz. rising and setting. Similarity between the sun’s movement and the instruction derived by the rich is quite essential here; otherwise no instruction can be derived from the sun who cannot directly impart any instruction by speaking etc. If the sun were to instruct some thing which is not similar to his own conduct, then his instruction would have proved useless and the ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§ï‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß between the sun and the rich would have failed. But the similarity between the sun’s conduct, and the instruction imparted give support to the ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§ï‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ. Then the ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ(which is not expressed but implied) helps the(possible) ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ßhere. Hence this is the second variety of ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ.

P. 67, LL. 12-19 ‚Äî‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§Ø… ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡•§ Here IndurƒÅja explains how the‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§ï‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ really exists (‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç) between ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É and ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç. ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç cannot impart any instruction as he cannot speak or make signs which will be understood by men. Thus it would appear at first sight that the connection of ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É and ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç expressed through ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§®‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æis impossible. But it will now be proved that the‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§ï‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß between ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É and ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç is real and consistent.

In a causal form there are always two subjects and two actions. One is the primary (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø) action which in this case is “understanding”. The other is the causal (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§ï) action which is “causing to understand” in this case. One subject is the ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ. He is the object of the causal action but subject of the primary action. The other is the ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ or ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§ï‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ who causes another to do something. Here ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç who makes to understand (‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç) is the ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ and ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É who understand (‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø) is the ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ. Now ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ is of two kinds one is direct and the other is in the form of ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§ö‡§∞‡§£; eg (1) ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø and (2) ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø. (1) ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§ causes some one to live.Here ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§ directly says “‡§â‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞” and makes the person stay. Thus ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§ becomes directly the ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å (producer) of ‡§µ‡§∏‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ. (2) Alms cause some man to stay (in a place). Here alms do not directly say to the man “‡§â‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äù etc. He gets plenty of alms in the place and therefore he is induced to stay there. Thus alms behaves in such a way asto make the man stay. This is called **‡§§‡§§‡•ç‚Äî(‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®)‚Äî‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§ö‡§∞‡§£.**In our present case also there is no direct causation and ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç is ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ. The sun does not directly instruct the rich people just as a teacher instructs his pupils. The sun only sets and the rich people derive their instruction from the sun’s setting. Hence ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§ö‡§∞‡§£.

P. 67, L. 18‚Äî‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§£‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡§£ is ordering and ‡§Ö‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§£ is requesting. These actions are present in directly causal subjects; they are absent in ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§ö‡§∞‡§£. For, the ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ is not capable of giving direct order by speech or otherwise. The MahƒÅbhƒÅshya of Pata√±jali contains a very clear exposition on this point of ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§ö‡§∞‡§£which is the basis of IndurƒÅja’s discussion. It has : ‚Äî ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å ‡§π‡§ø ‡§£‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∑‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï‡•á ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•å ‡§® ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§§ ‡§è‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§®‡•à‡§∑ ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§É‡•§ ‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§π‡•ã‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡•§ ‡§§‡•Ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§®‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∑‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•á ‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‚Äî‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•§ ‡§Ö. ‡•©‡•§ ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶ ‡•ß‡•§‡§Ü‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡•®‡•§ ‡§∏‡•Ç. ‡•®‡•¨‡•§

Thus although the sun is not the direct ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æit is still the ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ and the ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§ï‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß is existent and hence possible.

The ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞comments on the example very succinctly thus:‚Äî ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß ‡§â‡§™‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§∏ ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡•§ ‡§π‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§ï‡§É‡•§

** P. 67, L. 24‚Äî‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§É‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞**is the blending together of two figures. It is not an ala·πÖkƒÅraby itself, and as such its treatment should in the fitness of things be deferred till all other ala·πÖkƒÅrasare treated. Later writers like Ruyyaka and Mamma·π≠a have done the same thing. Even Da·πá·∏çin gives ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞the last place in his treatment of alankaras. BhƒÅmaha too has enumerated ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø(he has no ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞) at the end of all other ala·πÖkƒÅras.

‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞ according to Uabha·π≠a is of four types (1) ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞ ; (2) ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞ ; (3) ‡§è‡§ï‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞ and (4) ‡§Ö‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞.

P. 68, LL. 2-3‚Äî‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§ñ‡•á… ( KƒÅrikƒÅ62)‡•§‚Äî “[A sort of] ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞occurs when more than one ala·πÖkƒÅrasseem to exist; yet all of them cannot exist at a time; and there is neither any reason for nor any reason against accepting any of those ala·πÖkƒÅras[in preference to others]”.

P.68, LL. 4-20‚Äî‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§ñ‡•á…‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç….. ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§®‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡•§IndurƒÅja according to his usual habit takes‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§ñ‡•áas the primary epithet, and accounts for all other epithets one by one. If possibility of many ala·πÖkƒÅras(‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§ñ) is laid down as the sole condition then in ‡§è‡§ï‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞ also there exist many ala·πÖkƒÅra; e. g. ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡§æ etc. Here ‡§ó‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§µ ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ is ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ and ‡§®‡§∞‡§ï‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§®‡•Äcontains ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑. ‡§®‡§∞‡§ï‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä=(1) The destroyer of ‡§®‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞; (2) enemy (antidote) of hell. Thus the verse contains two ala·πÖkƒÅras and hence would claim to be ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞. To avoid the possibility of such examples becoming **‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞,**the words ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡§µ‡•áare put. The ala·πÖkƒÅras must be such as cannot exist at one time. If one is accepted the other must vanish. In ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡§æ etc. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑ and ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ can exist side by side.

Therefore it is not ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞. ‡§®‡§®‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã…… ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π ‡§è‡§µ‡•§ Even these two conditions do not sufficiently describe ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞. Two ala·πÖkƒÅras exist and both of them cannot exist at one time‚Äîthese two conditions are fulfilled. But there is some ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£ for one and ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£ for the other. Therefore the former is abandoned and the latter is accepted. Such an example will also fall under‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞. To exclude such examples, the condition viz. ‡§è‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö etc. is put. ‘When no reasons either for or against any ala·πÖkƒÅra exist and both ala·πÖkƒÅras are equally possible,’ then only it becomes ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞. The ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï and ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Ω must all be absent. If ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï and ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï are both existent then that ala·πÖkƒÅra having the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£ will be accepted and that having ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£ will be rejected. If only ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï is present the ala·πÖkƒÅra having the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£ will be accepted. If only ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï is present the ala·πÖkƒÅra having that‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï will be rejected and the other will be accepted. In all these cases there will be no ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞at all, one ala·πÖkƒÅrabeing totally rejected and the other accepted. Thus when all ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§ïs and all ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï‡§Çs are absent there is a possibility of ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞. Illustrations of all these cases having ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï or ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£s are given in ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂ - ‡•ß‡•¶, pp. 761-764 which may be consulted with advantage.

Our modern commentator ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ also cites examples in which the ala·πÖkƒÅrais determined by the existence of ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§ïor ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£s. It will be to our purpose to take down the passage here. ‘‡§Ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç’ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡•á, ‘‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§ø‡§∂‡§≠‡•É‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç’ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§ö‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‘‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡§∂‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§ø ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ã‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§µ ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§ø’ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á ‡§π‡§ø ‘‡§™‡§ø‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç’- ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‘‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç’ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§® ‡§π‡§ø ‡§∏‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ The last example is drawn from ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂. Further on he continues the discussion after the manner of ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂ and tries to assign & reason why Udbha·π≠a used the word ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï instead of ‡§â‡§≠‡§Ø in the KƒÅrikƒÅ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç-‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§ñ‡•á etc.. Thus he says‚Äî’‡§®‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ä‡§¶‡§§‡§ø’ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§®‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§ï‡§Ç, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§æ, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§£‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§®‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§ï‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç, ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§¨‡§π‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§≠‡§Ø‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§Æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

** P. 69, LL.11-12‚Äî‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ã**……‡•§ This is an example of ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞according to Udbha·π≠a; for in ‡§µ‡§∞‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Åthere is a possibility in his opinion of two ala·πÖkƒÅras ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ and ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï. The compound may be solved either as ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§É or ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ. This is according to Udbha·π≠a (and IndurƒÅja also). According to later canons of criticism this would not at all be an example of ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞. ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ and not ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï will be the ala·πÖkƒÅra here. The verse is addressed to PƒÅrvatƒ´ and we ought to have ‡§µ‡§∞as the word principally meant. If we accept ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï (‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§É) the ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø culminates on ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å and not on ‡§µ‡§∞. By ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ (‡§µ‡§∞‡§É ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ) we can have the word ‡§µ‡§∞ the prominent member in the compound. Therefore ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æis to be accepted and not ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï. The verb ‡§≤‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•áand all other words in the sentence are consistent with ‡§µ‡§∞and not with ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å. Thus there is no possibility here of ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞at all. Udbha·π≠a seems to have no idea of this line of thinking which is displayed in the works of Ruyyaka, Mamma·π≠a and other later writers.

P. 69, L. 22‚Äî‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á….(KƒÅrikƒÅ 63 a)‡•§ “When ala·πÖkƒÅras pertaining to words and those pertaining to sense appear (separately) in one sentence (or verse as the case may be) it becomes [a sort of] ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞.” This is the ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø of later writers. Ruyyaka says: ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç (‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç) ‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§§‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•Å‡§≤‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§®‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§É‡•§ ‚Äî‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ, pp. 192 and 197. ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø is of three kinds: (1) of two ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞s (of course occurring separately); (2) of two ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞s and (3) of one ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ and the other ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞. This third kind is the ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞of Udbha·π≠a. The other two kinds only are ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø(q. v. p. 78 of the text.) in his opinion.

P. 70, LL. 2-3‚Äî ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•ç …‡•§ Here ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏ is the ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ and ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏ is the ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞. ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏ (q. v. p. 34 of the text.) of Udbha·π≠a only require **‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ï‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ;**statement of ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø and ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑ is not required by him. Here ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á‡§£ ‡§§‡•á etc. is the ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ï of ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•É‡§•‡§æ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç. But according to the definition of Mamma·π≠a and other modern writers this figure will not be ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏. For both the statements are ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑. ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á‡§£ ‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ etc is a ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑(particular) statement; for it is addressed to PƒÅrvatƒ´ and pertains to PƒÅrvatƒ´’s case only.

Had it been ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§É ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã ‡§π‡§ø ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§Éit would have been a good example of ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏, for it would have referred to beautiful ladies in general and not to a particular lady.

P. 70, L. 12‚Äî‡§è‡§ï‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á … (KƒÅrikƒÅ 63b)‡•§ “‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞is also formed when two ala·πÖkƒÅras come together in a part of a sentence.” ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂is a word or a group of words that form a part of a sentence.

P. 70, LL, 16-17‚Äî‡§Æ‡•à‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ(‡§∏‡•ç‡§•) ‡§∏‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡•§ Here the ala·πÖkƒÅras ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æand ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑are present and both are expressed by the one word ‡§á‡§µ. The ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ is clear in ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§µ ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑ occurs in ‡§∏‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ and ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ. ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ means the pink colour of the lotus and the fair complexion of PƒÅrvatƒ´. Also ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§æis the central cup of the lotus, and ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£means the ear of PƒÅrvatƒ´. This ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑exists together with the ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æbecause the word ‡§á‡§µis present. If ‡§á‡§µis removed the ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æis lost and the double meaning of ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ and ‡§∏‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ is also lost. Thus the two ala·πÖkƒÅras ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑and ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æhave entered into one word ‡§á‡§µ.

The ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞has a very serious difference of opinion as regards the nature of the ‡§è‡§ï‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞ of Udbha·π≠a. While IndurƒÅja says that ‡§è‡§ï‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞ is a mixture of two ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞s, the ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ insists that this ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞ occurs when a‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞and an ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ combine in one ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂. He severely criticizes IndurƒÅja and explains the stanza ‡§Æ‡•à‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ etc. very differently. The whole of his comment on the stanza is worth quoting:‚Äî‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•å ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§∏‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•å ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§£‡•á ‡§ö ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§É‡•§ ‚Äò‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§®‚Äô‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡•á‡§¶‡§®‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§ The ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ is here acute and piercing. On the whole it seems to us that the‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞is in the right if we look to the wording of Udbha·π≠a.

P. 71, LL. 2-3‚Äî‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§ï or ‡§Ö‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•§‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£... (KƒÅrikƒÅ 64)‡•§ “When the ala·πÖkƒÅras are not independent of each other but exist by helping each other to develop, then that also is called ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞.”

P. 71, LL. 5-8‚Äî‡§â‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï……‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡•á‡§§‡§ø‡•§ The ala·πÖkƒÅrawhich helps another to develop clearly does some ‡§â‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞. And the ala·πÖkƒÅrawhich is thus helped indirectly does ‡§â‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ by being the receptacle of the help of the other. Thus both are **‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï,**helping each other.

P. 71, LL. 10-11‚Äî‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡§É…‡•§ Here there are three outstanding figures. ‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ is the ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ. ‡§Ö‡§®‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§means (1) not accpted, despised (‡§Ö‡§®‡•Ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§); and (2) deprived of body (‡§Ö‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§É). Hence it contains ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑. ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§® ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡§ø is (‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å) ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ, the cause (‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç) of the action of releasing being a fanciful one. Here the ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æis based on the first meaning of ‡§Ö‡§®‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§. It is only through boldness that a despised person does not leave the despiser. Thus here the ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑ in ‡§Ö‡§®‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§ helps the ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ and ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ also lends additional charm to the ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑. The ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ, ‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ, is also based onthe ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑ in ‡§Ö‡§®‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§; for ‡§Ö‡§®‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§ becomes the ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ.
PƒÅrvatƒ´ has abandoned (‡§Ö‡§®‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§) cupid; and ‡§π‡§∞has deprived cupid of his body (‡§Ö‡§®‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§). But according to Udbha·π≠a ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑is predominant wherever it occurs; other ala·πÖkƒÅrasare to be thrown to the back ground. Thus according to him ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑is the principal figure here and ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æand ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æare its accessories.

**P. 71, LL. 17 - 23‚Äî‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Ç … ‡§ö‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§É ‡•§**IndurƒÅja’s recapitulation of all the divisions of ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞described before.

It is to be noted that the names given to the four varieties of ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞are of IndurƒÅja’s invention. The KƒÅrikƒÅs do not contain any names of varieties.

The ideas of Da·πá·∏çin and BhƒÅmaha about ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞are not at all so elaborate and systematic as those of Udbha·π≠a, Da·πá·∏çin uses the words ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£and ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ørather promiscuously. BhƒÅmaha has only the name‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø.Exactly what kind of‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§øhe intends to put forth is not quite clear, either from his definition or from his examples. He has :‚Äî

‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡§π‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§∞‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡••
** ‚Äî‡§≠‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞, ‡•©, ‡•™‡•Æ,**

From the expression ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§µit seems that he does not want to include the ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞ of modern writers in his ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø, Da·πá·∏çinhas :-

‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§®‡§ø‡§ó‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§
‚Äî

‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞, ‡•®, ‡•©‡•´‡•Ø.

He has two varieties:-

‡§Ö‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ï‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡••
‚Äî

‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂, ‡•®, ‡•©‡•¨‡•¶.

It will be clear from this that Udbha·π≠ais greatly advanced in ideas about ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞beyond BhƒÅmaha and Da·πá·∏çin.

P. 71, LL. 25-26‚Äî‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞…‡•§ (KƒÅrikƒÅ 65) ‚ÄúWhen comparison (‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ) is reciprocal, the object being to remove the possibility of all other comparisons,[the figure] is called ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ.” ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ=the relation between ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® and ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø; comparison.

P. 72,LL. 2-11‚Äî‡§®‡§®‡•Å ‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç… ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•å ‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Øis that which being a party to the comparison is ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§ø‡§ï(belonging to the theme). Now in ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ the real ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Øis made ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® and the real ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® is made ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø. Thus the ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ of ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø will not be experienced in that case. Therefore the auothor says ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç. The chief object of ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ is to exclude the possibility of other ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®s. The real ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§µ and ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ of the respective tnings is not violated by reversing the ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µbetween them. By saying ‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•á ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ, one does not mean that the person addressed should eat poison. The chief intention is only to dissuade him from dining at a particular man’s house. In the same way the reversion of ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ is not important here, but the sense that there is no third thing comparable to the two things (‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® and ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø) is important. Thus in ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç, the sense that there is no third thing comparable to ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñand ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤is important and not the ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ.

** The ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ has :‚Äî**

‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡•§

BhƒÅmaha’s definition is‚Äî

‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§•‡•ã‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡••
‡§≠‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞- ‡•©, ‡•©‡•¨.

He probably uses the word ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø in the sense of **‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø.**Da·πá·∏çin calls this figure ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡§æand includes it under the varieties of ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ. Udbha·π≠a’s definition of this ala·πÖkƒÅrais a good one, that of Mamma·π≠a being too elliptical viz. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É‡•§ ‡§ï‡§æ. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞. ‡•ß‡•¶, p. 583.

**P. 72, LL. 12 - 13‚Äî‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ø ‡§™‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§µ …‡•§**Here ‡§ï‡§∞ and ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞are made ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø and ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® by tnrn. The real ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø is ‡§ï‡§∞, the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ is ‡§µ‡•á‡§ó‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§® (quick annihilation), the implication is that there is no third thing comparable to ‡§ï‡§∞and ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞in speedily destroying the enemies. This verse and the following upto verse 5, Varga VI are relative clauses connecting themselves with the principal clause ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡•à‡§ï‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡§Éetc. (verse VI. 5.).

In this verse it happens that ‡§ï‡§∞ and ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞ are both ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§ø‡§ïfor the prowess of ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å’s ‡§ï‡§∞ and ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞ both is described, and both therefore can be ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Øs. Thus there is no difficulty here. But in acase like ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç where one thing is ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§ø‡§ï and the other ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§ø‡§ï, the ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§ø‡§ï(viz. ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñhere) is always to be regarded as ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Øaccording to IndurƒÅja. Though it is expressed as ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® in ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç still by its real nature it is ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø and not ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®.

P. 72, LL. 21-22‚Äî‡§∏‡§π‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ … ‡•§‚Äî(KƒÅrikƒÅ 66) “When two actions taking place at the same time but depending upon two different things are described by one word (‡§™‡§¶), [the figure] is ‡§∏‡§π‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø.”

P. 72, L. 24-P. 73, L. 2‚Äî‡§®‡§®‡•Å ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡§π‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Éetc…….‡§® ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§ï ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§ IndurƒÅja says: In the example of ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§ï viz. ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡§π‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§É etc. (q. v. p. 15) also two actions concerning two different things are spoken of by
one word ‡§∏‡§ú‡§π‡§æ‡§∞. ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É and ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§¶‡§É are both objects of the verb. That is, the two different actions belonging to ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É and to ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§¶‡§É are indicated by the one word

‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡§π‡§æ‡§∞. Thus this example of ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§ï also would come under ‡§∏‡§π‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø. But such a possibilily is averted by the word ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á.The two actions must be taking place simultaneously, and from the construction of the ala·πÖkƒÅrathe simultaneous nature of the actions must be impressed on the reader’s mind. This is absent in ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§ï. In ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§∂‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Éetc. the destruction of ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É and ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§¶‡§É is not done at the same moment or occasion; first the‡§ï‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Éwere destroyed and consequently ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§¶‡§Éwere done away with. On this point ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ remarks‚Äî‡§® ‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§ï‡§§‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§è‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§£‡•ã‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§á‡§π ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§™‡§¶‡•Å‡§≠‡§Ø‡§ó‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§

** P. 73, LL. 2-9‚Äî‡§∏‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§ö‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§®… ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§** Now this is ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§§‡§æexpressed in two ways. (1) **‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§∏‡§π ‡§≠‡•Å‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•á‡•§**Here both the actions (of dining) are equally predominant and both have their respective subjects directly connected with the verb (2) ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§π ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡•§ Here ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§ is directly connected with the action of dining (‡§≠‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ) as ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§ is in the nominative case. But the connection of ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§ with ‡§≠‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ is through the word ‡§∏‡§π. This second sort of way of expressing ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§§‡§æ is resorted to in **‡§∏‡§π‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø;**for this is included in ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡§ø(indirect way of speaking). And ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡§ø must always be a necessary element in ala·πÖkƒÅras. The ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ similarly ramarks‚Äî‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ö‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡§π ‡§Æ‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§π‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§® ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ö‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•å ‡§∏‡§π ‡§≠‡•Å‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•á ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•§

** P. 73, LL. 12-13‚Äî‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ú‡§®‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡•ç….‡•§**Here the two actions are ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§∞‡§•‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ and ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ú‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§∞‡§•‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§£. They are expressed by the same words ‡§Ü‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§∞‡§•‡§É‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•á. Now these are two words and the definition says ‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•á. But the purportof the definition is to exclude two verbs separately expressing the actions concerning two things. And we have no such two verbs here. Only the verb ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•áexpresses the action concerning ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Åand ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ú‡§®. On the other hand the answer is that the action ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•áis a general one and without any particularizing attribute, it is quite incapable of conveying the sense. Therefore the particular ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§∞‡§•‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø is embraced by the general verb ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•áand the whole then appears as one word and not two. The ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞also remarks here‚Äî‡§Ü‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§∞‡§•‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§¶‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§µ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ã ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï-

‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§è‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§ï‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§ó‡§§‡•à‡§ï‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ö‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§™‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ï‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§∏‡§π‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

P. 73, LL. 25-26‚Äî‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•à‡§É… ‡•§ (KƒÅrikƒÅ 67) “Exchange of something with its equal, inferior or superior having an unacceptable, a positively disadvantageous and an acceptable nature respectively is called ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø.”

** **The order in ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Æ‡•çis changed in the translation. ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ means ‚Äòof acceptable nature.’ ‡§Ö‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ has been made to yield two meanings: (1) of indifferent and hence unacceptable nature; and (2) of positively harmful nature.

P. 74, L. 2‚Äî‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‚ÄîThat with which our thing is exchanged, i. e. the thing which we take. **‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‚Äî**Thething which we give for some other thing (‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï).

P. 74, LL. 3-14‚Äî‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É…… ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡•§The ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø in which equal things are exchanged is ‡§Ö‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µi, e. of not an acceptable nature. ‡§Ö‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§•means her ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É,absence of desirableness. In an exchange with equals there is no desirableness. The‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§øin which a superior thing is given for an inferior thing is also ‡§Ö‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ. Here ‡§Ö‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§• means ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§É the opposite of desirable i. e. harmful. Thus‡§Ö‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ made to yield two meanings. The six meanings of ‡§®‡§û‡•çare well known viz. (‡•ß) ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç (‡•®) ‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç (‡•©) ‡§§‡§¶‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç (‡•™) ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡•§ (‡•´) ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø- (‡•¨) ‡§Æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§®‡§û‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§É ‡§∑‡§ü‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•• Of these the sixth and the fourth are respectively made use of here. The ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§øin which an inferior thing is given and a superior thing is recieved is ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ, i. e. of a desirable nature.

P. 74, LL. 16-17‚Äî‡§â‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç…‡•§ Example of **‡§∏‡§Æ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø.**Here ‡§â‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ conveys ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§π by ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ. ‡§â‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡§æ‡§® is the means to display valour ; and it implies ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§π. Here ‡§â‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç and ‡§Ø‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç are regarded as equal to each other and hence **‡§∏‡§Æ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø.**The word ‡§Ø‡•á‡§®is connectsed with ‡§∏‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡•à‡§ï‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡§Éin verse 5, Varga VI.

P. 74, LL. 23-24‚Äî‡§®‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§∞‡§ó‡§¨‡§≤‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç…‡•§ Here some minor jewels are offered to the milky sea and the great jewel ‡§ï‡•å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§≠is taken in return. A paltry thing is given and a valuable thing is taken, Hence it is ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§®‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø; for the ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§øs

are named occording to the thing that is given. Of course this ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§øis of an acceptable nature.

**P. 75, LL. 2-3‚Äî‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¨‡§≤‡•å ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§ø…‡•§**A great thing such as ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§Øis given and a bad attribute such as ‡§ñ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§æisaccepted. Therefore it is ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã. This is really of a despicable nature.

P. 75, LL. 5-7‚Äî‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ… ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§IndurƒÅja here says that this example ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¨‡§≤‡•å ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§etc. is like the preceding one only in its outward sense.Looking to its purport we shall see that it is not ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§øat all. For‡§ñ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§æ(shortness) was voluntarily accepted by Vish·πáu (inthe ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞) as a means for giving ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§Øto Gods. Vish·πáu hasnot first given ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§Øto Gods and in return recieved ‡§ñ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§æfrom them. Therefore this is in its real nature not an exchange, and not ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§øalso.

Now the ala·πÖkƒÅra‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§øin itself is not constituted as IndurƒÅja imagines. ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ødoes not contain a real exchange at all. An imaginary description of exchange where there is no real exchange at all is **‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø.**Any real exchange such as ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§£‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡§¶‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§É cannot become charming and hence cannot be termed ala·πÖkƒÅraeven. In ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¨‡§≤‡•å ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§ etc. as well as in ‡§®‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§∞‡§ó‡§¨‡§≤ etc. and ‡§â‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç etc. there is no real exchange but only a poetical description of exchange.

This unreal nature of the exchange in ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§øis explicitly pointed out by JagannƒÅtha in his ‡§∞‡§∏‡§ó‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞. He says:‚Äî ‡§è‡§∑‡•Å (i. e. ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡•á‡§∑‡•Å) ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§®‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‚Äî ‚Äò‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§£‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§ö‡§≤‡•ã‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡§¶‡§∞‡§´‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§É‡•§’
‚Äî‡§∞‡§∏‡§ó‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞, p. 482.

BhƒÅmaha’s ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§øis quite of a different nature. It is this‚Äî

‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ã‡§π‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§®‡§É‡•§
‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡•å ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡••
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•§
‡§∏‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ñ‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡••
‡§≠‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‚Äî ‡•©, ‡•™‡•¶-‡•™‡•ß.

We do not know what has made him link ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏ with ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø. Probably his ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø does not include in it ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏; he is only giving in this place an example of ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø + ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏ and not only of ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø. To agree with this we have also ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ. ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä should not be included in the definition. It should refer to the example.

Udbha·π≠a’s definition of ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§øis deficient in one respect. He repeats the word ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®in the definition. Thus by putting a word. (viz. ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®) derived from the same root in the definition he leaves the word ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§øunexplained. More advanced writers like Ruyyaka and Mamma·π≠a have avoided this inaccuracy. They use the word ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§Øinstead of ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®. Thus Mamma·π≠a’s definition is :‚Äî

‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‚Äî‡•ß‡•¶. p. 674.

Similarly Ruyyaka has :‚Äî

‡§∏‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§®‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§®‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§
**‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‚Äî**p. 152.

  •        *

VARGA VI.

P.76, LL. 1-2‚Äî‡§Ö‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§Ç …… (KƒÅrikƒÅ 68 ) ‡•§‚Äî This is the last instalment of ala·πÖkƒÅras. This does not agree either with the enumeration of BhƒÅmaha nor with that of Da·πá·∏çin, though it bears some likeness to that of the former. BhƒÅmaha has :‚Äî

‡§∏‡§π‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§Æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡••
‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡•á‡•§
‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡•á‡§ß‡§∏‡§É‡••
‡§≠‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‚Äî ‡•©, ‡•©,‡•™.

of these ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§µ like ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï is altogether dismissed by Udbha·π≠a; and ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å and ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§ hehas added of his own. These two important ala·πÖkƒÅras are not mentioned by Da·πá·∏çin, BhƒÅmaha and VƒÅmans; and as far as our know-

ledge of the history of ala·πÖkƒÅras goes Udbha·π≠ais the first to introduce and treat these among the established ala·πÖkƒÅras. Probably because of their newness Udbha·π≠ahas mentioned them at the end of the whole list.

P. 76, LL. 3-6‚Äî‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø…… ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§ These lines display what an astute commentator and accurate grammarian IndurƒÅja is. The word ‡§á‡§§‡§øpresents a difficulty. ‡§á‡§§‡§øhas a conjunctive force and the substantives that are connected with ‡§á‡§§‡§øare always in the first case. Thus we can have ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§É ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§ú‡§Ø or simply ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§≠‡•ã‡§ú‡§Ø, but not ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§ú‡§Ø. But such an objectionable use of ‡§á‡§§‡§øis made by Udbha·π≠ain the KƒÅrikƒÅ. ‡§Ö‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§Ç etc. are governed by ‡§á‡§§‡§ø and still they are all in the accusative case. The word ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç stands for ‡§Ö‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø, ‡§∏‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§πetc. and it is in the accusative case in addition to‡§Ö‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§Çetc. IndurƒÅja finds a way out of the difficulty. He says that by the word ‡§á‡§§‡§ø, ‡§Ö‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç, ‡§∏‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§Ç etc. are not referred to at all. Therefore disregarding ‡§á‡§§‡§øwe can have ‡§Ö‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç, ‡§∏‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§Ç and others in apposition to ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç, and the second case thus becomes quite lawful. ‡§á‡§§‡§øis to be taken to mean ’ in the manner described afterwards‚Äô The ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞also has a similar remark on this point. He says‚Äî‡§á‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡•§ ‡§® ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§É‡•§

** P. 76, LL. 7-9‚Äî‡§Ö‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç……‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡§§=honoured, fit, venerable. ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Ç is a ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ compound. The general rule is that a word having fewer and shorter vowels should come first. (‡§Ö‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§™‡§æ ‡•®/‡•®/‡•©‡•™). But the exception to this rule is that a word signifying a more honoured or weighty object should precede the other members of the compound even if it is not composed of fewer and shorter vowels. Now in ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Ç, ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§ having more vowels is placed first, therefore it must be regarded as the more honoured and the more important figure of the two. This importance given to ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§ isthus accounted for by IndurƒÅja. There is ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø(q. v. under ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏) between the two parts of‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§** andtherefore‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§suggests the ala·πÖkƒÅra ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å(for ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Åalso contains ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø).

P. 76, LL. 11-12‚Äî‡§∏‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§É‡•§ ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ö…… (KƒÅrikƒÅ 69)‡•§“A statement containing a doubt [of the poet] who first expresses the sameness and then the difference [of the ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø] from the ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® in order to convey excellence [of the ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø] is called ‡§∏‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π by the wise.”

First the ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø is said to be the same as ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® in a doubtful manner; but afterwards some difference of the ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø from the ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® is set forth to convey the doubtful state of mind of the speaker. All this is done to eulogise the ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø.

P. 76, LL. 20-24‚Äî‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§É‡§∂‡•á‡§∑… ‡•§ **‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§É…‡•§**Here the conch-shell in the hand of Vish·πáu is first described as ‡§Ø‡§∂‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ö‡§Ø. In a ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï the manner of ascribing sameness is definite; here it is doubtful: ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§∂‡§É‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç etc. After this the difference is stated ‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•Ä‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§É‡§Ø‡§∂‡§É‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ö‡§Ø is not ‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•Ä‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§, on the contrary it spreads far and wide.

In the second stanza the same type of ‡§∏‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§πoccurs again. “Is this a swan come with a desire for the lotus in the form of the navel? But this is not moving [as a swan always is].” Here first the question is made whether ‡§Ø‡§∂‡§É- ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ö‡§Ø is the same as swan, but afterwards the differentiating quality is put forth, viz, ‡§®‡•à‡§∑ ‡§ö‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§≤‡§É.

** The ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞has a rather interesting note on these two stanzas. He says:-‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ñ ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§π‡§Ç‡§∏‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§ß‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ñ‡§É‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§≤‡§®‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡§µ‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§ø (?) ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§Ø‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ö‡§Ø ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶ ‡§â‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§É‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§¶‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•å ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§π‡§Ç‡§∏‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶ ‡§â‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡•§ ‡§π‡§Ç‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç‡§≠‡•á‡§¶ ‡§â‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡•§ Thus he interprets the‡§Ö‡§≠‡•á‡§¶** and the ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶ of the ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®s in a rather different way from that of IndurƒÅja.

P. 77, LL. 12-13‚Äî‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç…… (KƒÅrikƒÅ 70)‡•§ Another variety of ‡§∏‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π. “Any composition containing an apparent doubt when really there is no doubt, [set forth] with a view to produce a charm of other ala·πÖkƒÅras, is termed ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π.” It is to be noted that the name here is ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π and not ‡§∏‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π. The ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ remarks : ‡§∏‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§É.

P. 77, LL. 19-20‚Äî‡§®‡•Ä‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§∞‡•å….‡•§ ‚ÄúWho seated on the lord of birds, bright as the sun, is thus mistaken (by others): ‘Is this a dark cloud seated on the mountain Meru?’ or ‘Is this the smoke gathering on the fire of destruction?‚Äô” Here there is really no doubt in the mind of the speaker, whereas in the former variety the speaker himself was speaking in doubt. Here the poet says‚Äî‚Äò‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á, ‘who is thus mistaken.’ The poet himself is not at all mistaken; he only puts forth the possibility of a mistake on the part of others. Doubt is merely brought in here to express imaginary comparisons. The ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æhere produced is that of ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ.

** **Of course speaking from the standpoint of sheer commonsense, in both these varieties the doubts and comparisons are all the product of the poet’s imagination. There is no doubt or uncertainty about the real thing in the poet’s mind in both these varieties. The difference is only in the form and not in the substance.

The definition of ‡§∏‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§πof BhƒÅmaha is exactly the same as that of the first variety of Udbha·π≠a. But he has no second variety. Da·πá·∏çin has ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡§æinstead of ‡§∏‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§πwhich he illustrates thus:-

‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡•á ‡§≤‡•ã‡§≤‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§¶‡•ã‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡••
** ‚Äî ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂, ‡•®. ‡•®‡•¨.**

VƒÅmana’s definition of‡§∏‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π and his example are very similar to this.

Devotees of ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂will remember the wellknown line, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠ ‡§á‡§µ ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ (i. e. ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•á) ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§â‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü‡•á‡§®, of Mamma·π≠ƒÅchƒÅrya under ‡§∏‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π (‡§ï‡§æ. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞. ‡•ß‡•¶, ‡§™‡•É. ‡•´‡•Ø‡•ß.). It means : ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π is neglected by Bha·π≠·π≠odbha·π≠a, for there the is not conveyed by suggestion, but is actually expressed. For the charm exists in implication and not in bare expression. Udbha·π≠a has given three verses in all as examples of ‡§∏‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π. Therefore he could have easily inserted an example of ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§πif he had meant to include it. This fact indeed shows that he disregarded the‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π asMamma·π≠a remarks. But in

this work Udbha·π≠a does not any where say in so many words that he wants to exclude ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§πfor such and such reason. All other old writers viz. BhƒÅmaha, Da·πá·∏çin, and VƒÅmana do not give any example of ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π. Therefore they can also be said to have neglected that variety. Whether Udbha»õa had expressly written somewhere else condemning‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π for the reason given by Mamma·π≠a we do not at present know‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π is that where the end is made by a final decision after the doubts and fancies are expressed. The example given by Mamma·π≠a is:

‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ ‡§ï‡§≤‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§ú‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§≤‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§§‡§É‡••
** ‚Äî‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§É ‡•ß‡•¶, p. 590.**

** P. 78, LL. 2-3‚Äî‡§Ö‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø…...(KƒÅrika 71)‡•§ “When comparison of one thing is made with the thing itself in order to convey the absence of any other similar thing the ala·πÖkƒÅra is ‡§Ö‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø.” This definition of‡§Ö‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø** is the same as that of BhƒÅmaha.

Here also IndurƒÅja brings in the discussion that he dilated upon in‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø is the thing which is ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§ø‡§ï. How can it be the ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® which is always ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§ø‡§ï ? The answer is that such a discrepancy is allowed in ‡§Ö‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Øand ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ. For ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ is not the important element in them; the absence of any other similar thing is to be emphasised prominently.

In this KƒÅrikƒÅ also ‡§á‡§§‡§ø does not govern ‡§Ö‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç. If it did so‡§Ö‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø would have to be in the first case. It must be taken to refer to the example that follows.

**P. 78, LL. 13-14‚Äî‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä‡§µ….‡•§**The meaning of the verse and the ala·πÖkƒÅrain it are quite clear.

P. 78, LL. 18-19‚Äî‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§π‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç…..‡•§‚Äî(KƒÅrikƒÅ 72). “Sheltering together in one place [i. e. either in words or in sense] of many or even two ala·πÖkƒÅrasthat are independent of each other is called‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø”

** The respective provinces of‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø** and‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞as defined by Udbha·π≠a are different from those of more modern writers such as Mamma·π≠a and others. Two ala·πÖkƒÅrascan come

together in two ways. (1) They can be intermingled into one another so that one cannot be separated from the other. (2) They can be quite independent of one another the only connection between them being their coming together in one sentence or one verse. The first kind of combination is termed ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞by Mamma·π≠a and others and the second is called ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§øby them. Thus they have these two categories having a natural and fundamentaldifference between them. But Udbha·π≠a‚Äôs division is peculiar.He calls the first kind of combination (‡§∏‡§æ‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§â‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß) ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞. But he extends the province of ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞to the second kind of combination also. In it he makes a division. (1) The ala·πÖkƒÅras that ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§Ø‡§æcome together belong some of them to letters and some of them to sense promiscuously, the only tie being that they exist in one sentence or verse. Udbha·π≠a brands this as a variety of ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞. (2) The ala·πÖkƒÅras that come together either belong all of them to letters such as ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ï, ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏etc., or belong all to sense such as ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ, ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ïetc. This is. ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§øaccording to Udbha·π≠a (and IndurƒÅja also). It‡§∂will be thus seen that: **‡§è‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç (‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§è‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ (‡•ß) ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•á ‡§è‡§µ (‡•®) ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•á ‡§è‡§µ, (‡•©) ‡§â‡§≠‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§∏‡§æ….‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§É‡•§ (‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂; ‡•ß‡•¶,‡§™‡•É.‡•≠‡•´‡•®).**Out of these three categories (of ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø) set down by Mamma·π≠a the first two categories are the ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§øof Udbha·π≠a; the third category is **‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞.**The example given below illustrates the combination of two ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ω ( ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ and ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï).

**P. 78, LL, 26-27‚Äî‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡•à‡§ï‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡§É….‡•§ ‡§µ‡•à‡§ï‡•Å=‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§É ; ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø =**entering in, attaining, enjoying. Here two ala·πÖkƒÅras occur having no connection between them. ‡§∂‡§∂‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ã‡§∑‡§∏‡§ø ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡•çis ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æand ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§Ç is ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï(or ‡§¶‡•É‡§¢‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§ïaccording to ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡•ã‡§ú‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü.)

This is the culminating verse of the long sentence describing ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å. The sentence begins with ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§™‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§µetc, (Varga 5; st. 14.)

P. 79, L. 8‚Äî‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§Øis the directly expressed theme of description, The ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§Øis ‡§µ‡•à‡§ï‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡§§‡§øin this verse,

P. 79, LL. 1-2‚Äî‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§ß‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®…..‡•§This is not an example of ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø. It is a verse in the poem inserted to keep the chain of the story unbroken. But to free it from the charge of uselessness IndurƒÅja says that this verse should be appended to the former and the whole should be considered as an example of‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø of many (not two) ala·πÖkƒÅras in consideration of the ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æcontained in ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡•á.

P. 79, LL. 13-14‚Äî‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§á‡§µ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§É … ‡•§(KƒÅrikƒÅ 73) “When wonderful things that belong either to past or to future are seen as if they are perceptible to the eye by the unimpeded power of words then the ala·πÖkƒÅrais‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï. "

P. 79, LL. 15-16‚Äî‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§®… ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§®…‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡•§ These are definitions in the ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø style. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ = the non existence of a thing before its production. This ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ has not a beginning but has an end. ‡§Ö‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É, ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•§ ‚Äî‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ = the non-existence of a thing after its destruction. This ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§æ‡§µhas no end but has a beginning.‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É, ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•§‚Äî‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§É.

** ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§æ‡§µs are of four kinds :‚Äî**

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É‚Äî(described above), e.g. ‡§á‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§® ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É‡•§

** ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É‚Äî**(described above), e.g ‡§á‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É‡•§

** ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É‚Äî**e.g. **‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§≤‡•á ‡§ò‡§ü‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡•§**The total absence of any thing.

**‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É‚Äî**e.g. ‡§ò‡§ü‡§É ‡§™‡§ü‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡•§ The absence of one thing in another.

P. 79, L. 18‚Äî‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ï… ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§ By casting of the now existing ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ or ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ.

** P. 79, LL.21-22‚Äî‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§…‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§** ‡§Ö‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§§‡§æis the unimpededness of language; conveying the meaning quickly by the use of well-known words and absence of involved construction (‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß).

P. 79, L.22,‚ÄîP. 80, L. 4‚Äî‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç… ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ It is to be noted that Udbha·π≠a has used the word ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•áin his

definition. His aim is: It is not at all sufficient that the poet should only describe absent things as perceptible to the eye. The reader must also see and feel the things as such. And for this purpose there must be enough of force (‡§Ö‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§§‡§æ) in the style of the poet and enough of wonderfulness in the things themselves. IndurƒÅja lays stress on this point in the passage. When there is (‡§Ö‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§§‡§æ) force and vividness in the style, the ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ or the feelings of the poet are experienced by the appreciative readers as the reflection produced by that poetry, and are felt by them as forcibly as by the poet himself. Their own feelings converge on the thought as their minds are melted by the forcible words. Therefore they also see those things, described in the poem as presented to the eye, for the things become as intimate to their feelings as they were to those of the poet. As a forcible and vivid description is a cause of this process so also wonderfulness of the theme is a cause of it too.

**P. 80, LL. 5-6‚Äî‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ…..‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•á‡•§**Occurs in BhƒÅmaha (3; 53). BhƒÅmaha has:‚Äî

‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§á‡§µ ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡••‡•©;‡•´‡•®.
‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç……‡•§‡•©;‡•´‡•©.

P. 80. LL. 9-10‚Äî‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•É‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•É‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á ‡§Ö‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡•á‡§® ‡§Ö‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§ = definitely established as the same. The thought of the poet is identified with the thought of the reader in ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï.

** P. 80, LL. 12-15‚Äî‡§∞‡§∏‡•ã‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§µ‡•á‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ……‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•…….‡•§** Whence these stanzas are taken cannot be determined ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø = getting himself reflected [in ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§£]. The subject is ‡§ï‡§µ‡•á‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ.

**P. 8O, LL. 20 - 21‚Äî‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§∑‡§ø ‡§™‡•Ä‡§°‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç …‡•§**PƒÅrvatƒ´generates pain (‡§™‡•Ä‡§°‡§æ) because she is without any ornament (‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∑‡§£) or ‡§Ö‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§® etc. She evokes pleasure (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø) because she is so beautiful that the charm of ornaments is seen in her without the ornaments themselves. Thus the ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∑‡§£‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß(the wearing of ornaments) which existed

before is here expressed as seen by the eye. The reader as well as the poet feels as if the ornaments are present on the body of PƒÅrvatƒ´. This constitutes ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï. This expression is not verbal as in ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∑‡§£‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç. It is implied by the words ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§∑‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç and ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§∞‡§£‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§Ø‡§æ. In ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∑‡§£‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç the poet himself says: ‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á,‚ÄòI see before myself your figure with the future ornaments.’

P. 81, LL. 2-3‚Äî‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§É (-‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ç)‡•§‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞.….. (KƒÅrikƒÅ 74)‡•§ “When one thing heard becomes the cause of calling to mind or experiencing some other thing, the ala·πÖkƒÅrais called ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó.”

P. 81, LL. 5-8‚Äî‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ…… ‡§â‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§¨‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§ The terms ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ and others are explained before under ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏. (See Notes pp. 60-61) IndurƒÅja’s point of assertion is that the ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Ås that are detailed by logicians are quite insipid and harsh; but ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Åwhich is set in composition that is rich in flavour and is intensely appealing to the heart of all people (i. e. in poetry) cannot but be charming.

P. 81, LL. 8-10‚Äî‡§Ö‡§§‡§É…… ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ Therefore the name ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§óis quite appropriate. For it suggests the oppositeness of ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó (i.e. the logical ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®) which is insipid.

**P. 81, L. 15‚Äî‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§§‡§æ‡•§**Tendency to help the manifestation of rasa (sentiment).

**P. 82, LL, 6‚Äì9‚Äî‡§Ø‡•Å‡§µ‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó…..‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ö‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§Ç‡•§……**These verses are found in VƒÅmana’s ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø on ‡•©. ‡•ß. ‡•®. Authorship of them is uncertain. They express the same thing that VƒÅmana puts in his ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ - ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É‚Ä¶..etc.‡•§**‡•©,‡•ß, ‡•ß-‡•®-‡•©,**and may possibly belong to VƒÅmana himself.
The meaning is clear.

P. 82, LL. 14-15‚Äî‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã……‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§Ø‡§π‡•á‡§§‡§µ‡§É…‡•§‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É‡•§ VƒÅmana’s ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞s ‡•©. ‡•ß. ‡•ß-‡•®-‡•©.

**P. 82, L. 17‚Äî‡§Ö‡§®‡§ø‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß=**Either (1) not artificial, natural; or (2) not impeded, rushing head long. The first meaning is more desirable; the second meaning does not agree with the epithet ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Äwhich means oozing, dribbling.

P. 82, LL. 18-21‚Äî‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•å …..‡•§‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§∂‡§§‡§ï, ‡•≠‡•´This example is brought in to show that the best form of poetry can exist without ala·πÖkƒÅras but not without gu·πáas. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø=reunion, re-agreement ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§ñ‡§≤‡§® or ‡§ó‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§ñ‡§≤‡§® = an unconscious slip of a secret thing, e. g. the unconscious utterance of the name of the ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï or ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ, ‡§â‡§™‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï or ‡§â‡§™‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ. The translation: When the dear one who had some how effected a reunion, unconsciously dropped some hints (of his secret intercourse), the lady emaciated by separation feigned non-hearing; and having found the apartment empty with a glance that was hasty on account of the fear lest the unpardoning ‡§∏‡§ñ‡•Ämight have heard it (the ‡§ó‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§ñ‡§≤‡§®), breathed a sigh of relief.

The lady was in separation and the lover was attached to another woman. The lover afterwards came and by ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§§‡§®etc. effected an agreement. But in talking he dropped some hints of his secret connection. The lady had of course some spark of jealousy of this, but she being ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§π‡§ï‡•É‡§∂was eager for union. But if the ‡§∏‡§ñ‡•Ä(these ‡§∏‡§ñ‡•Äsare always very obdurate people) had been there she would not have allowed union so meekly. Therefore when the lady saw that ‡§∏‡§ñ‡•Äwas not present she sighed in relief. Here by ‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•å it is suggested that there was ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§π‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠ before and there is an agreement (‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø) now. By ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ñ‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•áthe ‡§à‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠or the jealousy (of the ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ) is suggested.By ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§π‡§ï‡•É‡§∂‡§Ø‡§æit is suggested that the jealousy aroused in the mind of ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï‡§æis subdued, for she was too emaciated to suffer separation any longer. By ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§π‡§®‡§∏‡§ñ‡•Äetc. it is suggested that if the‡§∏‡§ñ‡•Ähad heard the ‡§ó‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§ñ‡§≤‡§®she would again have caused ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§π(separation), with thisfear the ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ looked around and when ‡§∏‡§ñ‡•Äwas not seen ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó was again established (‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç etc.) Thus here ‡§à‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠ and ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§π‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠ vanish giving place to ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó.

‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§∂‡•É‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞ is of five kinds: ‚Äô‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∑‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§π‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§∂‡§æ‡§™‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§ï ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§É‡•§’‚Äî‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂ ‡•™, p. 102. The terms explain themselves. More detailed treatment of these and ‡§∞‡§∏s in general should be seen in ‡§¶‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï, ‡•™ ; or in ‡§∞‡§∏‡§§‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä,

P. 81, L. 11, to P. 84, L. 9‚Äî ‡§®‡§®‡•Å ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§£‡•á‡§®etc………….‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ In this passage IndurƒÅja enters into a short but very valuable dissertation on the nature of poetry. He discusses the relative importance of ala·πÖkƒÅras, gu·πáas and rasas in poetry. And his views on these topics form a blend of the dogmas of the old and new as well as the Kashmirian and non-Kashmirian schools of thought. All this should be read in the original. Only a summary of it is attempted here.

First, how does the use of the word ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø in ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó for instance, implies ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§µi. e. richness in flavour? The answer is: Because a ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Øis ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏as its form consisting of words and sense is polished by gu·πáas (merits). The gu·πáas are ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Øsweetness, ‡§ì‡§ú‡§∏‡•çfloridity, and ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶a lucidity. Of these‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶is the chief, as it is always essential for an easy expression of (‡§∞‡§∏) the sentiment. Thus the outer body of poetry being furnished with these merits, especially ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶, which are helpful to the manifestation of the sentiment, poetry itself becomes in its essence rich in sentiment. The ala·πÖkƒÅras are additional ornaments to poetry which is primarily and principally embellished by gu·πáas. As a woman having natural excellences (gu·πáas) receives additional charm from ornaments so also the charm of poetry, primarily endowed by gu·πáas, is heightened by ala·πÖkƒÅras. Gu·πáas can be charming without ala·πÖkƒÅras, but ala·πÖkƒÅras are useless in a place where there are no gu·πáas. VƒÅmana says‚Äî‡§Ø‡•Å‡§µ‡§§‡•á‚Äî‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó etc.,‚Äî‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ö‡§É etc.,‚Äî‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡•©, ‡•ß, ‡•ß‡•¶. Poetry is no poetry without merits or gu·πáas. But without ala·πÖkƒÅras poetry can exist. Similarly he says‚Äî“Producers of charm in poetry are gu·πáas, and the elevators of that charm are ala·πÖkƒÅras; the former (i. e. the gu·πáas) are essential‚Äù,‚Äî‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡•©, ‡•ß, ‡•ß - ‡•®-‡•©. Even examples of poetry, having no ala·πÖkƒÅras but having gu·πáas, are seen; e.g. the verse of Amaru≈õataka containing a flow of intense erotic sentiment, viz. ‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•åetc.‚Äî‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§∂‡§§‡§ï ‡•≠‡•´.In this verse no ala·πÖkƒÅra is seen. It attains a poetical form by the presence of the gu·πáa ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶ helped by ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø and ‡§ì‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç. One may say that ‡§∞‡§∏‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞exists here; for here the sentiments ‡§à‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠ and ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§π‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠ vanish and the ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡§∂‡•É‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞

develops in their stead. But that is not true, For sentiments (‡§∞‡§∏s) are not of the nature of ala·πÖkƒÅras. The ‡§∞‡§∏s are the soul of poetry and words and sense are the body. Ala·πÖkƒÅras are the ornaments of words and sense. Therefore rasas (i. e. the soul) cannot be said to be the ornaments of the outer body. Hence in the above verse, ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó helped by the vanishing ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠ is the soul and not an outer embellishment of the poetry. The same is the case with other ‡§∞‡§∏s, ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µs, ‡§Ü‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏s of ‡§∞‡§∏ and ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ and their ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§Æs etc. As to what is said before (in this work) that rasas constitute ala·πÖkƒÅras, such as ‡§∞‡§∏‡§µ‡§§‡•çetc., it is said in a condition when this discrimination about the real nature of ‡§∞‡§∏s was not meant (by the author). ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§ etc…….‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç. Now if a ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø is ‡§∏‡§ó‡•Å‡§£ and ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏, ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ and ‡§≠‡§∞‡§§(‡§®‡§æ‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞) cannot be a ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø ; for it has neither ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£s nor ‡§∞‡§∏s. But then this will go against the verse of BhƒÅmaha, viz.‚Äî ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ etc. (‚Äî‡§≠‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡•ß, ‡•ß‡•≠), in which he says that works dealing with arts and sciences are one of the four varieties of a ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø. This conflict is removed by applying the word ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Øto sciences and arts in a secondary sense (‡§â‡§™‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞). The principal sense of ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Øis always ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§Ç etc. It is applied to ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•by its secondary sense which it gets on account of the similarity of ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§• with ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§∏‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§• (poetry) as both of them are literary compositions. Thus this much is clearly established that ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ódoes not belong to insipid compositions just like ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó; but it always belongs to compositions rich in flavour on account of the ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£s that exist in it.

Various points inviting consideration suggest themselves to us when we read this short yet important passage of IndurƒÅja.

The first point that presses itself upon our consideration is: Whether the views of IndurƒÅja on ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Øbelong to the Kashmirian or to the non-Kashmirian school of ƒÅla·πÖkƒÅrikas. The obvious answer to the question may be that IndurƒÅja belongs essentially to the Kashmirian and the ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§øschool; and generally it is correct. IndurƒÅja

speaks of ‡§∞‡§∏as the soul of a ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Øand speaks of ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£s and ala·πÖkƒÅras as the ornaments of the body of poetry. He has only three gu·πáas and not ten as propounded by Da·πá·∏çin and VƒÅmana. So far his views are at one with the Kashmirian school of ƒÅla·πÖkƒÅrikas. But there are also some very marked differences between the views of that school and his own views. In the first place he gives the utmost importance to gu·πáas and says after VƒÅmana that poetry having no gu·πáas is no poetry at all‚Äî‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç‡§π‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø(p.82). This view, we have already said (vide, Introduction pp. xviii-xx), is the view of the non-Kashmirian writers. Further, in IndurƒÅja’s opinion gu·πáas are the embellishments of the body ( i. e. the style and language) of poetry and they help the manifestation of ‡§∞‡§∏‚Äî‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç (p. 84,1.3.). This view is refuted by Mamma·π≠a who says : ‚Äî’‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§® ‡§è‡§µ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∂‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§∞‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ ‡§® ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç’ ‚Äì ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂ ‡•Æ, p. 463. In respect of these gu·πáas the ideas of IndurƒÅj√† follow Da·πá·∏çin and VƒÅmana to a great extent. Yet he tries to harmonise the theory of ‡§∞‡§∏with the dogmas of VƒÅmana which are to some extent irreconcilable with the ‡§∞‡§∏ theory. Thus he says ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç, ‘Poetry is rich in sentiment because its form consisting of words and sense is embellished by gu·πáas,’ which is almost meaningless from both points of view. For VƒÅmana does not at all recognise ‡§∞‡§∏, and ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏in his opinion is a useless word. The modern writers would never say that a ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Øis rich in sentiment because the outer form of it is embellished by gu·πáas. They do not accept that gu·πáasare the cause of the manifestation of ‡§∞‡§∏. But IndurƒÅja says ‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•å‡§ú‡•ã‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§â‡§™‡§¨‡•É‡§Ç‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•á. IndurƒÅja has too much followed VƒÅmana to be able to reconcile himself with the ‡§∞‡§∏and ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§øtheory which he wants to establish.

The gu·πáas are the attributes of sentiments (‡§∞‡§∏) and not of the body (i. e. ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶ and ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•, words and sense) of a ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Øaccording to Mamma·π≠a and others. But the non-Kashmirians such as Da·πá·∏çinand VƒÅmana make gu·πáas the attributes of ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡•Ä(style), which is the principal element of a ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Øin their opinion. Rƒ´ti is determined according as

it contains or excludes the various gu·πáas and thus gu·πáas have come to be of primary importance in their treatment. The pioneers of the ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§øtheory hold that ‡§∞‡§∏is the main element of poetry and gu·πáas are quite unimportant. Now IndurƒÅja admits that ‡§∞‡§∏is the soul of poetry, but he also wants to give so much importance to gu·πáas that his discussion ceases to harmonise with the‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§øtheory.

Another question that suggests itself is whether all these views expressed by IndurƒÅja were also shared by Udbha·π≠a. No definite answer to this question can be obtained in this state of our knowledge. IndurƒÅja has brought all this discussion about the nature of poetry while explaining the KƒÅrikƒÅ of Udbha·π≠a, viz.‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞….(KƒÅrikƒÅ 74), and generally it is the custom of commentators not to propound any view that is unacceptable to the author. If they propound such views in the body of the commentary, they would generally affix some such words: ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡•áetc.‚Äîw–µ for ourselves think‚Äîdenoting some difference with the author. IndurƒÅja makes no such remark; on the contrary he has brought in this subject in the course of explaining the title ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó (against ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó) given by Udbha·π≠a. He wants to say that the word ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó (as against ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó) is used to express ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡§§‡§æ. And to explain this ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡§§‡§æhe brings in the discussion about rasas and gu·πáas. Thus it would seem from his way that all those views which he has set forth are shared by Udbha·π≠aand he has adopted the title ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ówith all those views in mind.

Approaching the question from another point of view, an altogether different state of things presents itself to us. Udbha·π≠a, as we have seen, is the follower of the system of BhƒÅmaha and not of Da·πá·∏çin and VƒÅmana.
